Paid-on-call firefighters probationary period will go through a period of one year after completion of minimum qualifications, which is FF II and EMT. 
(c)  Promotions shall be subject to a one year probationary period. If employees who have been promoted are found unsuitable for the work of the positions to which promoted, they may be reinstated to the position and rate of pay of the position from which promoted, so long as a vacancy exists. Employees that have served in an interim promotional position may be determined to have successfully completed the probationary period at the discretion of the city administrator. 
(d)  Transfers and reclassifications shall be subject to a one year probationary period. If employees who have been transferred and/or reclassified are found unsuitable for the work of the positions to which transferred and/or reclassified, they may be reinstated to the position and rate of pay of the position from which transferred and/or reclassified, so long as a vacancy exists. Employees that have served in an interim transfer and/or reclassified position may be determined to have successfully completed the probationary period at the discretion of the city administrator. 
(e)  Prior to employees having completed their probationary service, their respective department directors shall evaluate their records and performances. If the employee's records and performances are satisfactory, the department director shall so certify to the city administrator. Upon determining that the employee has successfully completed the probationary period, the city administrator may designate the employee as a regular employee. If the employee's records and/or performances are found to be unsatisfactory at any time during the probationary period, the department director shall so certify to the city administrator and the city administrator may terminate the employee immediately. If employee performances are found to be marginal during the probationary period, the city administrator may agree to an extension of the probationary period to permit further possible satisfactory development. 
(Ord. No. 1597, § 1597.01, 8-11-93; Ord. No. 1708, 10-11-2000; Ord. No. 1742, 1-14-2004; Ord. No. 1814, § 1814.04, 2-11-2009; Ord. No. 1847, § 1847.01, 12-14-2011; Ord. No. 1931 , § 1, 12-14-2016; Ord. No. 1958 , § 1, 1-23-2019) 
Sec. 2-203. - Resignation. 
(a)  Any non-supervisory employee wishing to leave the city service in good standing shall file with his/her department head at least ten working days before leaving a written resignation stating the effective date of the resignation. Any employee designated as a supervisor shall provide such notice at least 15 working days before the effective date of resignation. Any employee designated as a department head shall provide such notice at least 20 working days before the effective date of resignation. Failure to comply with this procedure may be considered cause for denying such employee future employment by the city and denying terminal leave benefits. The city administrator may revise the effective date of the resignation upon the needs of the city or the employee. An employee's termination date may not be extended by applying unused sick, personal, holiday or vacation time. The separation of employment date is always the employee's last day worked, or in some cases, the last day of his or her approved leave of absence. Holidays and use of accrued vacation, personal and sick hours during the notice period shall not be counted as working days. 
(b)  Unauthorized absence from work for a period of three working days may be considered by the department head as a resignation without benefits. 
(c)  Nothing in this provision modifies the at-will employment status in any way. 
(Ord. No. 1597, § 1597.01, 8-11-93; Ord. No. 1742, 1-14-2004; Ord. No. 1847, § 1847.01, 12-14-2011; Ord. No. 1961 , § 1, 4-10-2019) 
Sec. 2-204. - Relationship to other city personnel. 
    Applicants shall not be appointed as a regular full-time or part-time employee if any of the following exist: 
(1)  The applicant is a relative of a current elected official, the city administrator, the administration services director, or any confidential employee of the city; or 
(2)  The applicant's spouse is a current employee of the city and the spouse has the authority to hire, supervise, evaluate, or discipline the person seeking employment, or if the spouse's position is classified as confidential; or 
(3)  The employment of the applicant is related to the official responsibilities of an existing employee who is related to the applicant. Paid-on-call firefighter and seasonal employees are exempted from this paragraph of the policy, with the exception that no paid-on-call firefighter or seasonal employee shall be appointed to a position where a relative has the authority to hire, supervise, evaluate or discipline the person seeking employment. 
    For the purposes of this section, the term "relative" means any of the following: father, mother, husband, wife, son, daughter, brother, sister, uncle, aunt, niece, nephew, first cousin, father-in-law, mother-in-law, brother-in-law, sister-in-law, son-in-law, daughter-in-law, or any step relations of the preceding. 
(Ord. No. 1708, 10-11-2000; Ord. No. 1727, 4-24-2002; Ord. No. 1728, 5-22-2002; Ord. No. 1814, § 1814.03, 2-11-2009; Ord. No. 1847, § 1847.01, 12-14-2011; Ord. No. 1902, § 1, 5-27-2015 ) 
Editor's note- At the city's instruction, Ord. No. 1708, adopted Oct. 11, 2000, replaced § 2-204 which derived from Ord. No. 1597, § 1597.01, adopted Aug. 11, 1993. Formerly, § 2-204 pertained to retirement. 
Sec. 2-205. - Physical and psychological examination for continued employment. 
    A condition of employment for every employee is the employee's ability to perform the duties of the position satisfactorily. Every employee shall demonstrate his physical, mental, and emotional fitness to perform his/her work. The employer may require a yearly physical and/or psychological examination. If a examination is ordered by the city for an employee the city will pay for the examination. 
(Ord. No. 1597, § 1597.01, 8-11-93; Ord. No. 1902, § 1, 5-27-2015 ) 
Sec. 2-206. - Layoffs. 
    Fourteen calendar days after written notice, the city administrator, following approval by the city council, may lay off regular employees because of shortage of work or funds, abolition of positions, or other reasons. The city administrator may lay off or terminate temporary or seasonal employees with no prior notice and without city council approval. 
(Ord. No. 1597, § 1597.01, 8-11-93) 
Sec. 2-207. - Regular work day and week. 
    Except for certain sworn employees in the police department and full-time firefighters, the full-time regular work week shall be 40 hours, generally with at least two consecutive days off each week and the regular day generally shall be eight working hours. Supervisors may require their employees to work overtime in situations where it is required in order to ensure the orderly and efficient operation of the government. Employees designated as exempt from overtime according to the provisions of the Fair Labor Standards Act may require additional working hours as needed to complete the responsibilities of the position. 
(Ord. No. 1597, § 1597.01, 8-11-93; Ord. No. 1742, 1-14-2004) 
Sec. 2-208. - Activities incompatible with employment-Generally. 
(a)  A city employee shall not engage in any employment, activity or enterprise which is inconsistent, incompatible or in conflict with his/her duties as a city employee, or with the duties, functions and responsibilities of the department by which he is employed. 
(b)  The following activities shall be considered inconsistent, incompatible or in conflict with city employment: 
(1)  Any employment, activity or enterprise which involves the use for private gain or advantage of the city's time, facilities, equipment or supplies, prestige or influence of a city office or employment. 
(2)  Involves the receipt or acceptance by the officer or employee of any money or other consideration from anyone other than the city for the performance of an act which the officer or employee would be required or expected to render in the regular course of his/her city employment or a part of his/her duties as a city officer or employee. 
(3)  Involves the performance of an act in other than his/her capacity as a city officer or employee which may later be subject directly or indirectly, to the control, inspection, review, audit or enforcement by such officer or employee or the department by which he/she is employed. 
(4)  Involves so much of the employee's time that it impairs his/her attendance or efficiency in the performance of his duties as a city officer or employee. 
(Ord. No. 1597, § 1597.01, 8-11-93) 
Sec. 2-209. - Same-Political activity. 
(a)  No employee shall participate in activities that involve the public employee's use of his or her official authority or influence to compel a person to apply for membership in or become a member of a political organization, to pay or promise to pay a political contribution, or to take part in political activity. 
(b)  Employees are free to engage in any political activity of their choice provided it does not conflict with subsection (a). 
(Ord. No. 1597, § 1597.01, 8-11-93; Ord. No. 1742, 1-14-2004) 
Sec. 2-210. - Same-Outside employment. 
    Employees may not engage in outside employment or business interests which would conflict with their job or might in any way hinder their objective and impartial performance of their public duties, embarrass the city government, or impair their efficiency on the job. 
    Employees with employment or business interests in addition to their city employment with employers or businesses that have or could have a financial relationship to the city shall disclose this information to the city. 
(Ord. No. 1597, § 1597.01, 8-11-93; Ord. No. 1847, § 1847.01, 12-14-2011; Ord. No. 1902, § 1, 5-27-2015 ) 
Secs. 2-211-2-119. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PAY PLAN AND COMPENSATION 

Sec. 2-220. - Establishment of pay plan. 
    There shall be at all times a pay plan for all classes of positions included in the classification plan. Such plan shall be established, and from time to time amended, by city council resolution upon receipt of recommendations from the city administrator. In making such recommendations, the city administrator shall give appropriate consideration to the following factors: 
(1)  Maintenance of equitable relationship between classes, based on their relative duties and responsibilities. 
(2)  The general level of rates in the appropriate labor markets for comparable work under similar conditions. 
(3)  Current recruitment and retention experience. 
(Ord. No. 1597, § 1597.01, 8-11-93) 
Sec. 2-221. - Content of pay plan resolution. 
    The pay plan resolution shall contain the assignment of classes to pay grades, the minimum, standard and maximum pay in each grade, and the method of normal progression through the pay grade. 
(Ord. No. 1597, § 1597.01, 8-11-93; Ord. No. 1708, 10-11-2000) 
Sec. 2-222. - Total compensation, travel expenses, etc. 
(a)  The rates of pay set forth in the pay plan are for regular full-and part-time employment and represent the total salary compensation in every form except as otherwise provided in this section. 
(b)  The pay rate in the basic schedule of salary grades shall not be considered to include allowances for authorized travel or other expenses incurred in city business or allowance made to employees for the official use of personally owned automotive equipment. 
(c)  An employee shall be reimbursed for expenses incurred while conducting business for the city. Reimbursement shall be for, but not limited to, mileage, meals, lodging, travel tickets, telephone calls and shall be approved in accordance with policy. In order to receive such reimbursement, the employee shall fill out the appropriate claim form and submit it to their department or division director for consideration and approval. Mileage allowance for the use by an employee of his/her own automobile shall be reimbursed at the rate allowed by IRS guidelines. 
(d)  Special fees or compensation which an employee may receive or be authorized by law to collect while in the employ of the city and performing his/her assigned duties shall be paid to the city in full. 
(e)  As provided for in Minnesota law, all employees are required to participate in direct deposit. 
(Ord. No. 1597, § 1597.01, 8-11-93; Ord. No. 1708, 10-11-2000; Ord. No. 1814, § 1814.05, 2-11-2009; Ord. No. 1847, § 1847.01, 12-14-2011; Ord. No. 1902, § 1, 5-27-2015 ) 
Sec. 2-223. - Deductions from pay. 
    Any employee may authorize deductions from his/her pay for the following purposes: 
(1)  City employee group insurance. 
(2)  Charitable organizations withholdings. 
(3)  Employee organization dues and fees. 
(4)  Assignments and additional withholdings. 
(5)  Deferred compensation or health savings plans. 
(6)  Retirement. 
(7)  Flexible spending accounts. 
(8)  Tax withholdings. 
(9)  Court ordered withholdings. 
(Ord. No. 1597, § 1597.01, 8-11-93; Ord. No. 1847, § 1847.01, 12-14-2011; Ord. No. 1902, § 1, 5-27-2015 ) 
Sec. 2-224. - Pay period. 
    All employees in the city service shall be paid on a biweekly basis on Friday, with the exception of paid-on-call employees, who shall be paid on a monthly basis on Friday. In the event that pay day falls on a holiday, the pay day will be on the preceding work day. Pay checks shall not be issued other than on regular pay days except at the discretion of the finance director. 
(Ord. No. 1597, § 1597.01, 8-11-93; Ord. No. 1708, 10-11-2000; Ord. No. 1847, § 1847.01, 12-14-2011) 
Sec. 2-225. - Part-time, intermittent and hourly employment. 
    In those cases where a person is employed in a class on an intermittent basis, the employee shall be paid the hourly equivalent ( 1/80 in the case of a forty-hour week) of the appropriate biweekly rate for each hour worked. 
(Ord. No. 1597, § 1597.01, 8-11-93) 
Sec. 2-226. - Pay plan administration. 
(a)  Generally. The city administrator shall be responsible for administering the pay plan according to this section. 
(b)  Beginning salary rate. The beginning rate for a new employee normally will be the minimum rate in the established grade for his/her classification. A pay rate above the minimum rate may be authorized to: 
(1)  Meet difficult recruiting problems or to obtain a person with marked superior qualifications. 
(2)  Correct salary inequities or give credit for prior service. 
(c)  Method for within range salary increases. After appointment or promotion an employee shall be eligible for advancement through his/her respective pay grade based on the method of normal progression through the pay grade as specified in the pay plan resolution. 
(d)  Date for salary increase. Scheduled pay increases shall be made effective at the beginning of the pay period during which the required qualifying service and compliance with the other conditions of eligibility set forth in subsection (c) are completed. 
(e)  Promotion pay. Upon promotion, an employee shall be placed at the minimum wage in his/her new pay grade, except that in cases where this would not be a pay increase the promoted employee shall be placed in such position in the new grade as may be necessary. Upon completion of one year's service, the provisions of subsection (c) shall apply to the promoted employee. 
(f)  Reclassification pay. Upon reclassification to a class having a higher pay grade, an employee shall be placed as close to his/her same salary in the new grade as they occupied in the old grade, without resulting in a reduction in pay. The employee shall receive no less than the minimum pay of the new grade. 
(g)  Change of class in pay grade. Upon the movement of a class to a higher pay grade, all employees in the class at the time of the change shall be placed as close to their same salary in the new grade as they occupied in the old grade, without resulting in a reduction in pay. Upon the movement of a class to a lower pay grade, the employees in the class at the time of the change will not be reduced in pay unless such action is specifically called for by the resolution moving the class to a lower pay grade. 
(h)  Adoption of new pay plan. Upon adoption of a new pay plan resolution, the method for initial implementation of the new plan shall be established by resolution, except that whenever possible adoption and implementation of a new plan shall not affect the established anniversary date of any employee. 
(i)  Reporting pay. Regular full-time employees who report for work at a regularly scheduled time on a regular work day and are sent home by their supervisor because the work cannot be performed shall receive a minimum of two hours' pay. 
(j)  Overtime pay and compensatory time off. Overtime is all time ordered and worked in units of one-quarter hour or more, which is in excess of 40 hours per week for all Fair Labor Standards Act nonexempt, unrepresented employees. Compensation shall be monetary at one and one-half times the employee's regular hourly rate or earned compensatory time at one and one-half times the amount of overtime worked. 
(k)  Overtime approval. All overtime must be approved by a department director or division director prior to any employee working overtime. 
(l)  Compensatory time off. Nonexempt, unrepresented employees may elect to receive time off based on accrued compensatory time provided the employee has the approval of his/her department director or division director. 
(m)  Eligibility for overtime or compensatory payment. All nonexempt, unrepresented employees shall be eligible for overtime or compensatory time payment. 
(n)  Compensatory accrual. No nonexempt, unrepresented employee shall be able to accrue more than 20 hours of compensatory time. If an employee has accrued 20 hours of compensatory time and has approval for overtime the overtime will be compensated monetarily at one and one-half times the employee's regular base rate. Employees with accrued compensatory time not used by December 1 of each year will have the remainder of their compensatory time paid off monetarily by the city at a rate equal to the employee's regular hourly rate. 
(o)  Call back. A regular employee given less than 24 hours' notice for a call back to duty at a time other than his/her normally scheduled work period shall be compensated at the employee's regular pay rate for hours worked outside of the scheduled work period. An employee who is called back to work after completing his/her regular work day shall receive a minimum of two hours pay. An extension or early report to work does not qualify the employee for the two hours minimum. 
(Ord. No. 1597, § 1597.01, 8-11-93; Ord. No. 1708, 10-11-2000; Ord. No. 1814, § 1814.06, 2-11-2009; Ord. No. 1847, § 1847.01, 12-14-2011; Ord. No. 1902, § 1, 5-27-2015 ; Ord. No. 1958 , § 2, 1-23-2019) 
Secs. 2-227-2-238. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - EMPLOYEE BENEFITS 

Sec. 2-239. - Generally. 
(a)  Benefits shall be those granted to all regular full-time or regular part-time employees employed 30 hours or more per week including but not limited to: 
(1)  Medical insurance. 
(2)  Dental insurance. 
(3)  Holidays. 
(4)  Call back pay. 
(5)  Court pay. 
(6)  Reserved. 
(7)  Unused sick leave pay. 
(8)  Mileage reimbursement. 
(9)  Vacation. 
(10)  Sick leave. 
(11)  Injury on duty. 
(12)  Military pay. 
(13)  Jury duty. 
(14)  Life insurance. 
(15)  Long-term disability insurance. 
(16)  Short-term disability insurance. 
(17)  Retirement (if eligible). 
    For all regular part-time employees employed 30 hours or more per week, vacation, holiday and sick leave benefits shall be accrued on a prorated basis. 
(b)  Effective January 1, 2000, benefits shall be granted on a prorated basis based on the employee's budgeted full-time equivalency (FTE) to all regular part-time employees employed 20 hours or more per week including: 
(1)  Unused sick leave pay. 
(2)  Vacation. 
(3)  Sick leave. 
(4)  Holiday pay. 
(5)  Additional vacation based on low sick leave usage. 
(c)  Nothing in this division shall be construed to take the place of any union contract provisions for benefits negotiated and agreed to by the union and the city. 
(d)  The city council shall establish the limits of each employee benefit annually by resolution. 
(Ord. No. 1597, § 1597.01, 8-11-93; Ord. No. 1700, 12-14-99; Ord. No. 1708, 10-11-2000; Ord. No. 1847, § 1847.01, 12-14-2011; Ord. No. 1902, § 1, 5-27-2015 ) 
Sec. 2-240. - Vacation leave. 
(a)  Vacation leave for regular full-time unrepresented employees shall be accrued as follows: 
0 through 5 years of service Is calculated at .0385 hours per annual scheduled hours. (e.g., 80 hours per year for 2080 annual scheduled hours) 6 through 10 years of service Is calculated at .0577 hours per annual scheduled hours. (e.g., 120 hours per year for 2080 annual scheduled hours) Beginning of 11th year or service Calculation of an additional .00385 hours per annual scheduled hours, per year, up to a maximum annual calculation of .0769 hours per annual scheduled hours. (e.g., maximum of 160 hours per year for 2080 annual scheduled hours)  
    Regular part-time unrepresented employees shall accrue vacation leave on a prorated basis based on their budgeted full-time equivalency. Effective December 25, 2005, regular full-time unrepresented firefighters shall accrue vacation leave on a prorated basis to the above schedule based on their annual full-time hours scheduled. 
    The city administrator may establish a higher level of accrual and/or an accrued bank for employees as a recruitment or retention tool. 
(b)  Employees using earned vacation shall be considered to be working for the purpose of accumulating additional vacation leave. 
(c)  Vacation leave may be used subject to approval of the department heads or their designee(s). No vacation may be used until completion of three months of service. 
(d)  Regular full-time unrepresented employees may carry over from one calendar year to the next up to 192 hours of accrued vacation leave. Regular part-time unrepresented employees may carry over vacation leave on a prorated basis based on their budgeted full-time equivalency. Unrepresented firefighters may carry over vacation leave from one calendar year to the next up to 0.0923 hours per annual scheduled hours of accrued vacation leave (i.e. 211 hours carry over for 2288 annual scheduled work hours). 
(e)  Employees leaving the municipal service in good standing and having given proper notice of termination shall be compensated for vacation leave accrued and unpaid computed to the date of separation. 
(Ord. No. 1597, § 1597.01, 8-11-93; Ord. No. 1697, 10-27-99; Ord. No. 1700, 12-14-99; Ord. No. 1723, 9-26-2001; Ord. No. 1726, 4-24-2002; Ord. No. 1737, 7-23-2003; Ord. No. 1773, 5-10-2006; Ord. No. 1847, § 1847.01, 12-14-2011; Ord. No. 1902, § 1, 5-27-2015 ; Ord. No. 1958 , § 3, 1-23-2019) 
Sec. 2-241. - Sick leave. 
(a)  Authorized uses. Sick leave is not considered a privilege that an employee can use at will, but sick leave use is authorized for the following reasons: 
(1)  In case of personal illness, injury, disability, legal quarantine, to receive medical or dental care or for outpatient or inpatient treatment for mental illness, employee assistance program, alcoholism or drug addiction; 
(2)  A family health matter related to an employee's spouse, dependent, child or parents; 
(3)  Up to six weeks following the birth of a child for the female who has given birth. In the case of a female employee who has gone through childbirth, a longer period of time may be granted for sick leave use depending on the period of recovery. In this case, the employee must submit a doctor's statement indicating the length of time she will be unable to physically return to work; 
(4)  Up to two weeks following the birth of a child for the father or adoptive parents who have not given birth themselves. In the case where the father is needed to care for the spouse or child due to medical reasons of the spouse or child, or the adoptive parents are needed to care for the child due to medical reasons of the child, a longer period of time may be granted for sick leave use depending on the period of recovery. In this case, the employee must submit a doctor's statement indicating the length of time he or she will be needed to care for the spouse or child due to medical reasons; 
(5)  In case of a serious illness in the immediate family. Immediate family means brother/step-brother, sister/step-sister, parents/step-parents, parents-in-law, spouse, or children/step-children of the employee. 
(6)  For the purpose of attending a funeral of immediate family as described in subsection (a)(3) plus brothers-in-law, sisters-in-law, sons-in-law, daughters-in-law, grandparents, grandparents-in-law, and grandchildren/step-grandchildren of the employee. Up to three work days may be used for this purpose per occurrence (hours applied will be prorated based on the employees annual scheduled work hours). If attending the funeral requires out-of-state travel, additional sick leave may be used upon prior approval of the city administrator. 
(b)  Accrual. Sick leave shall accrue, but shall not be available until after one month of employment. Sick leave shall accrue for regular full-time employees at the rate of 3.70 hours per bi-weekly pay period or as provided for by resolution until 800 sick hours have been accumulated. An employee who accumulated 800 sick hours shall accrue additional sick leave at a rate of 1.85 hours per pay period. Regular part-time employees shall accrue sick leave on a prorated basis based on their budgeted full-time equivalency. 
    Effective December 25, 2005, regular full-time unrepresented firefighters shall accrue sick leave at .0462 hours per annual scheduled hours until 0.3846 per annual scheduled hours have been accumulated (i.e. 880 hours sick leave for 2,288 hours worked annually). A regular full-time unrepresented firefighter who has accumulated 0.3846 hours per annual scheduled hours shall accrue additional sick leave at .0231 per annual scheduled hours. 
    The city administrator may allow reinstated employees their unredeemed sick leave balance that was present upon their resignation. 
    Employees using earned vacation leave or sick leave shall be considered working for the purpose of accumulating additional sick leave. Workers' compensation benefits shall be credited against the compensation due employees during sick leave. 
(c)  Eligibility. In order to be eligible for sick leave with pay, employees must: 
(1)  Notify their superior prior to the time set for the beginning of their normal work day. 
(2)  Keep their superior informed of their condition if the absence is of more than two days' duration. 
(3)  Submit doctor's certificates for absences if required by the city administrator. 
(d)  Use when not eligible. Employees claiming sick leave when physically fit, except as otherwise permitted in this section, shall be cause for disciplinary action. 
(e)  Unused sick leave pay. Regular full-time employees who have been employed for at least ten consecutive years shall have paid out to them 50 percent of their accumulated and unused sick leave, up to a maximum of 600 hours (or 0.2885 hours per annual scheduled hours for regular full-time unrepresented firefighter), at the time of their resignation, retirement, or death (at which time such sick leave shall be paid to the employee's beneficiary). Regular part-time employees shall receive such unused sick leave benefit pay on a prorated basis based on the employee's budgeted full-time equivalency. If discharged for cause, unused sick leave pay shall not be allowed. 
(f)  Earning additional vacation hours. Nonexempt, unrepresented regular full-time employees employed by the city as of January 1 of the year in consideration who have used under 20 hours of sick leave annually are eligible to earn the following additional vacation hours: 
Hours of Sick Leave Bonus Vacation Under 8 hours 0.00 to 8.00 8.00 Under 16 hours 8.01 to 16.00 6.00 Under 20 hours 16.01 to 20.00 4.00  
    Regular part-time employees are eligible to receive additional vacation based on low sick leave usage on a prorated basis to the above schedule based on the employee's budgeted full-time equivalency. 
    Effective December 25, 2005, regular full-time unrepresented firefighters as of January 1 of the year in consideration who have used under .0096 hours per annual scheduled hours of six leave annually are eligible to earn the following additional vacation hours. 
Hours of Sick Leave Bonus Vacation Under .0038 hours per annual scheduled hours 0.00 to.0038 hours per annual scheduled hours .0038 hours per annual scheduled hours Under .0077 hours per annual scheduled hours .0038-.0077 hours per annual scheduled hours .0029 hours per annual scheduled hours Under .0096 hours per annual scheduled hours .0077 to .0096 hours per annual scheduled hours .0019 hours per annual scheduled hours  
  
(Ord. No. 1597, § 1597.01, 8-11-93; Ord. No. 1637, §§ 1637.01, 1637.02, 8-23-95; Ord. No. 1686, § 1686.01, 11-30-98; Ord. No. 1700, 12-14-99; Ord. No. 1708, 10-11-2000; Ord. No. 1724, 3-27-2002; Ord. No. 1726, 4-24-2002; Ord. No. 1742, 1-14-2004; Ord. No. 1773, 5-10-2006; Ord. No. 1847, § 1847.01, 12-14-2011; Ord. No. 1902, § 1, 5-27-2015 ; Ord. No. 1958 , § 3, 1-23-2019) 
Sec. 2-241.1. - Donated sick or vacation leave. 
(a)  With the express written approval of the city administrator, city employees having accrued sick and/or vacation leave will be allowed to donate a portion of such accrued sick and/or vacation leave to fellow employees experiencing a major disease or condition suffered by the employee, their spouse, or minor children, or for the purposes of the employee in attending a funeral of a relative as defined in subsection 2-241(a). A major disease or condition shall include, but not necessarily be limited to, heart attack, stroke, organ transplant, or life threatening illness or condition as defined by a physician's diagnosis. 
(b)  The donation of sick and/or vacation leave from one employee to another shall be subject to the following terms and conditions: 
(1)  An employee is only eligible to receive donated sick and/or vacation leave for time lost from work due to a major life threatening disease or condition as described above, equal to the number of hours of time, compensated by sick leave, vacation leave, or compensatory time, which the employee would lose from his or her job due to major life threatening disease or condition. An employee is only eligible to received donated sick and/or vacation leave for time lost from work to attend a funeral of a relative as described in subsection 2-241(a), equal to the number of hours of time the employee would have been eligible to use of his or her own sick, vacation, or compensatory time leave for the purpose of attending the funeral, as described in subsection 2-241(a). Unused donated sick or vacation leave will be returned to the donor(s). 
(2)  An employee will be eligible to receive donated sick and/or vacation leave only after the employee's accrued sick leave, compensatory time and vacation have been used by the employee. A newly hired employee who is not yet eligible to take his or her own vacation leave may receive and use vacation leave for the purposes outlined in this section. 
(3)  No employee will be allowed to receive more than 160 hours of donated sick and/or vacation leave for any single major life threatening disease or condition without the additional express approval of the city administrator. The value of the donated sick or vacation leave is computed according to the salary or wages of the recipient, regardless of the salary or wage of the donor. 
(4)  An employee may donate no more than 16 hours of sick and/or vacation leave combined per calendar year to a single fellow employee. This shall not be construed to prohibit 16 hours each year to additional fellow employees. An employee may donate leave only if that employee will have a remaining balance of at least 40 hours of vacation leave and 40 hours of sick leave after the donation. 
(5)  A written request to donate sick and/or vacation leave must be made to the city administrator on forms designated by the city for that purpose. 
(6)  The city administrator shall have the right to deny use of donated sick and/or vacation leave or limit its use as shall be determined necessary in the best interests of the city. 
(Ord. No. 1588, § 1588.01, 9-9-92; Ord. No. 1719, 5-23-2001; Ord. No. 1742, 1-14-2004; Ord. No. 1902, § 1, 5-27-2015 ) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1588, § 1588.01, adopted Sept. 9, 1992, enacted provisions pertaining to donated sick leave designated as § 2-286. Such provisions have been redesignated with the city's consent as § 2-241.1 for purposes of classification. 
Sec. 2-242. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1708, adopted Oct. 11, 2000, deleted § 2-242 which pertained to severance pay and derived from Ord. No. 1597, § 1597.01, adopted Aug. 11, 1993; Ord. No. 1700, adopted Dec. 14, 1999. 
Sec. 2-243. - Military leave. 
    Employees ordered by proper authority to National Guard or reserve military service in time of war or other properly declared emergency shall be entitled to leave of absence without pay during such service. Upon completion of such service employees shall be entitled to the same or similar employment of like seniority, status, and pay as if such leave had not been taken, subject to the specific provisions of Minn. Stats. Ch. 192. 
(Ord. No. 1597, § 1597.01, 8-11-93) 
State Law reference- Salary differential payments for certain state employed military reserve members, Minn. Stat. § 43A-183; compensation of city officers and employees on military leave, Minn. Stat. § 192.26. 
Sec. 2-244. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1847, § 1847.01, adopted December 14, 2011, repealed § 2-244, which pertained to relief periods (breaks) and derived from Ord. No. 1597, § 1597.01, 8-11-93. 
Sec. 2-245. - Holiday leave. 
    Unrepresented regular full-time employees shall receive 16 personal holiday hours (which shall be prorated for mid-year hire dates) and the following designated holidays per year. Regular part-time employees shall receive a prorated amount of personal holiday and regular holiday hours based on their budgeted full-time equivalency. In the case of a holiday falling on a Saturday the preceding Friday will be the observed holiday, and in the case of a holiday falling on a Sunday the following Monday will be the observed holiday (includes * holidays). In the case of Christmas Eve day and Christmas day falling on Sunday and Monday, there will be an additional personal holiday for that year. 
    If an unrepresented exempt employee works scheduled hours, as authorized by the supervisor, on any of the following designated holidays, that employee shall be provided additional personal holiday hours equal to the time worked. If an unrepresented, non-exempt regular full-time or regular part-time employee works on any of the following designated holidays (including the Easter holiday), as authorized by the supervisor, that employee shall receive one and one-half times the employee's regular rate of pay for hours worked on the actual holiday (not the observed holiday). 
New Year's Day* 
Martin Luther King Day Observed 
Memorial Day Observed 
Independence Day* 
Labor Day Observed 
Veteran's Day* 
Thanksgiving Day and day following Thanksgiving 
Christmas Eve Day* 
Christmas Day* 
    Effective December 25, 2005, regular full-time unrepresented firefighters shall receive personal holiday hours based on .0077 per annual scheduled hours (which shall be pro-rated for mid year hire dates) and shall receive holiday pay of .0384 per annual scheduled hours. 
(Ord. No. 1597, § 1597.01, 8-11-93; Ord. No. 1667, 12-17-97; Ord. No. 1700, 12-14-99; Ord. No. 1708, 10-11-2000; Ord. No. 1726, 4-24-2002; Ord. No. 1773, 5-10-2006; Ord. No. 1787, 1-24-2007; Ord. No. 1847, § 1847.01, 12-14-2011; Ord. No. 1902, § 1, 5-27-2015 ; Ord. No. 1931 , § 1, 12-14-2016) 
State Law reference- Holidays defined, Minn. Stat. § 645.44, subd. 5. 
Sec. 2-246. - Injury leave. 
(a)  Leave of absence with pay shall be granted to regular employees who become incapacitated as a result of injury or occupational disease incurred through no misconduct of their own while in actual performance of assigned duties. Leave shall be a maximum leave with pay of 90 working days. The time shall not be charged against the employee's leave vacation or other accumulated benefits. The city agrees to pay the difference, if any, between workers' compensation benefits, insurance coverage, including no-fault, and the employee's regular weekly pay up to the maximum leave with pay. The employer shall review each case and shall make a determination on the employee's eligibility for such leave. 
(b)  Any employee who is receiving workers' compensation benefits because of job connected injury or sickness shall, if he/she assigns his/her check to the city, receive full wages for that period. If an employee is receiving worker's compensation benefits and does not assign his/her check, he/she will be paid for the difference between the workers' compensation allowance and his regular weekly pay. Sick leave shall then be figured on a prorata basis with no deduction of leave being made for that portion of the employee's absence which is covered by workers' compensation insurance. 
(c)  Injury leave shall extend for a maximum of 90 days, unless it is determined sooner by competent medical authority, that the employee can return to duty. 
(d)  An employee who is physically incapacitated and who fails to report the injury within 48 hours followed by a written report within seven days, any injury, however minor, to his/her foreman or supervisor and to take such first aid or medical treatment as may be necessary shall not be eligible for injury leave. 
(Ord. No. 1597, § 1597.01, 8-11-93) 
Sec. 2-247. - Leaves for jury duty, attendance at conventions and other meetings. 
    When an employee performs jury duty or is subpoenaed as a witness in court, he/she is entitled to compensation equal to the differences between his/her regular pay and the amount received as juror or witness fees. Such time off shall be considered time on duty. 
    Attendance at conventions and other meetings and visits to other cities shall be considered as time on duty; provided, that such attendance is approved in advance and in writing, by the department head and is consistent with budget approval. 
(Ord. No. 1597, § 1597.01, 8-11-93; Ord. No. 1847, § 1847.01, 12-14-2011) 
Sec. 2-248. - Leave without pay for employees. 
(a)  Special leaves without compensation include: 
(1)  Personal leave. Upon the request of an employee, special leave of absence without pay may be granted by the city administrator, who shall take into consideration good conduct, length of service, the efficiency of the employee, and the general good of the city service. Leaves of absence without pay may only be requested after all vacation leave (and sick leave if for medical purposes) have been exhausted. Such leave of absence shall not exceed a period of 90 days, provided that the same may be extended beyond such period if the leave of absence is for continued disability or other good and sufficient reasons, but in no case shall the personal leave without pay exceed one year except when the employee is disabled for disability incurred while in performance of the employee's duties as an employee of the city. 
During the leave period, the employee will not accrue or be able to use accrued vacation, holidays, and sick leave. Employees on special leave without compensation shall have the option of continuing to participate in the city's health, dental, life and disability insurance by agreeing to pay the full premium of said coverage pursuant to procedures established by the finance director, but in no case shall this option exceed 18 months. 
(2)  Family and Medical Leave Act (FMLA). All employees who have worked for the city for a cumulative period of 12 months and have worked at least 1,250 hours for the city during the 12-month period prior to requesting a leave are eligible for up to 12 weeks of family or medical leave per 12-month period for either a birth, adoption or foster care placement of a child; to care for a spouse, parent or child who has a serious health condition; for a serious health condition of the eligible employee, or for "any qualifying exigency" arising out of the fact that an employee's spouse, son, daughter, or parent is on active duty or has been notified of an impending call to active duty status in support of a contingency operation. Spouses employed by the city are entitled to a combined total of 12 work weeks of family leave for the birth or placement of a child for adoption or foster care, and to care for a parent (but not a parent-in-law) who has a serious health condition. Accrued vacation, personal, and sick leave (for the medical portion of the leave) may be used as a part of the 12-week FMLA leave. An eligible employee who is the spouse, son, daughter, parent or next of kin (closest blood relative) of a covered service member who is recovering from a serious illness or injury sustained in the line of duty while on active duty, is entitled to up to 26 weeks of leave in a single 12-month period to care for the service member. This is a one-time 26 week leave provision that does not renew each FMLA year. A medical certification verifying the illness/injury will be required in order for this leave to be used. 
A minimum 30-day notice must be given prior to the date on which the leave is to begin. If 30 days cannot be given for unforeseen leave needs, the employee will give as much notice as practicable. Requests for leaves must be in writing and approved by the city administrator. 
a.  Accrued sick leave may be used as defined in City Code section 2-241(a) sick leave-authorized uses. 
b.  The city will continue to provide the employee with full benefits when an employee uses sick leave, vacation, or floating holiday(s) during the approved FMLA leave. 
c.  An employee on FMLA leave who is not using sick leave, vacation, or floating holiday(s) shall not be eligible to accrue any leave benefits during the leave. The city will continue to pay the normal portion of health, dental, life, and disability insurance as if the employee were working. An employee who is on unpaid leave must pay his or her portion of the premium of the said coverage if coverage continuation is desired during the leave, pursuant to procedures established by the finance director. 
(3)  Parental leave. All regular full-time and part-time employees who do not qualify for FMLA leave, who work an average of 20 hours or more per week and have successfully completed 12 months of employment may be granted a leave of absence from work by the city administrator provided that the employee is a natural or adoptive parent in conjunction with the birth or adoption of a child. The length of leave shall be determined by the employee, but may not exceed 12 weeks. 
Parental leave time shall begin at the time requested by the employee. The leave may not begin more than 12 months after the birth or adoption. The employee shall notify their supervisor in writing at least 45 days before the expected commencement date of parental leave. The leave shall be unpaid except as follows: 
a.  Accrued sick leave may be used as defined in City Code section 2-241(a) sick leave-authorized uses. 
b.  The city will continue to provide the employee with full benefits when an employee uses sick leave, vacation, or floating holiday(s) during the approved leave. 
c.  Leave without pay for parental purposes shall be considered medical leave only for that portion of the leave which the employee is medically unable to return to work, as certified by a licensed medical doctor. 
d.  An employee on parental leave who is not using sick leave, vacation, or floating holiday(s) shall not be eligible to receive any benefits during the leave but shall have the option of continuing to participate in the city's health, dental, life, and disability insurance by agreeing to pay the full premium of the said coverage pursuant to procedures established by the finance director, but in no case shall this option exceed 18 months. 
(4)  Military leave for families. The city will not discharge from employment or take adverse employment action against an employee because an immediate family member is in the military forces of the United States, or this state. Nor will the city discharge from employment or take adverse employment action against an employee because they attend the following kinds of events relating to the military service of an immediate family member. Employees should complete a "Request for Employee Leave" form as soon as practicable, marking the appropriate category, and submit it to their supervisor as soon as practicable. The unpaid leave may not exceed two consecutive calendar days or six days in a calendar year. Employees may substitute paid leave if they choose to do so. 
a.  Military ceremonies, family training, and reintegration for spouse, parent or child. This leave applies to immediate family members defined as a person's spouse, parent, or child. An employee shall be granted a leave without pay to: 
i.  Attend departure or return ceremonies for deploying or returning personnel; 
ii.  Family training or readiness events sponsored or conducted by the military; 
iii.  Event held as a part of official military reintegration programs. 
b.  Military ceremonies for extended family members. This leave applies to immediate family members defined as a person's grandparent, legal guardian, sibling, grandchild, fiancé or fiancée, spouse parent or child. An employee whose immediate family member has been ordered to active service in support of a war or other national emergency, shall be granted a leave without pay to attend a send-off or homecoming ceremony for the mobilized service member. Time off is for the actual time necessary for the employee to attend the ceremony, not to exceed one unpaid day in any calendar year. Employees may substitute paid leave if they so choose. The City may deny such leave if the leave would unduly disrupt the operations of the city. 
c.  Military member injured/killed in active service. This leave applies to immediate family members defined as a person's parent, child, grandparents, siblings, or spouse. An employee shall be granted a leave without pay for up to ten working days for an immediate family member, who as a member of the U.S. Armed Forces, has been injured or killed while engaged in active service. An employee must give as much notice as practicable of their intent to exercise the leave guaranteed above. Employees may substitute paid leave if they choose to do so. This leave will run concurrently with any other applicable leave. For an unpaid absence of up to ten working days, an employee will accrue leave and the city will pay insurance contributions as if they were still at work. 
(b)  Conditions governing all leaves without pay. 
(1)  With the return from unpaid leaves, employees shall be entitled to all sick leave and vacation leave accrued prior to the leave which was not used during their absence. 
(2)  Failure of an employee to request an extension before the expiration of leave shall be considered a voluntary resignation. 
(3)  An employee granted unpaid leave of absence shall have the right to return to employment in the original job or position of like status and pay unless the employee's position has been discontinued or the employee would have been laid off if such employee had not been on leave. The city administrator shall have the right to place said employee in a position which most efficiently promotes the city welfare. 
(4)  If an employee had not yet completed his or her probationary period prior to beginning a leave of absence, his or her probationary period shall be extended by the amount of the leave of absence upon return. 
(5)  An employee returning from a leave is entitled to retain all unused accrued pre-leave benefits of employment and seniority as if there had been no interruption in service. 
(6)  An employee, by agreement with the city administrator, may return to work part-time during the leave period without forfeiting the right to return to employment at the end of the leave period. 
(Ord. No. 1597, § 1597.01, 8-11-93; Ord. No. 1708, 10-11-2000; Ord. No. 1724, 3-27-2002; Ord. No. 1814, § 1814.07, 2-11-2009; Ord. No. 1931 , § 1, 12-14-2016) 
Secs. 2-249-2-259. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - DISCIPLINE 

Sec. 2-260. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1720, adopted Aug. 8, 2001 deleted § 2-260 which pertained to causes for action and derived from Ord. No. 1597, § 1597.01, adopted Aug. 11, 1993; Ord. No. 1708, adopted Oct. 11, 2000. 
Sec. 2-261. - Appeals and hearings. 
(a)  An employee who has a grievance may avail himself/herself of the grievance procedure in this section. Such employee must submit his/her appeal in the following sequence: 
(1)  First step, his/her department director or division director. 
(2)  Second step, the city administrator. 
(3)  Third step, the city council. 
(b)  An appeal shall be in writing. 
(c)  Employees shall be entitled to representation of their own choosing in appealing any grievance. Employees shall be entitled to one representative at the first step in the grievance procedure and any reasonable number of representatives thereafter. When necessary in investigating and settling a grievance, employees and their representatives shall be released from work without loss of pay for a reasonable amount of time, provided department directors or supervisors are given sufficient advance notice to adjust work schedules. 
(d)  The decision in an appeal shall be made as follows (except that failure to receive a decision shall entitle the employee to appeal at the next step): 
(1)  Any employee, or group of employees, having a grievance shall file the grievance in writing with his/her department or division director within 21 working days after the alleged incident has occurred. The decision in the first step shall be rendered within five working days of presenting the grievance at the first step level. The employee may appeal the first step decision by filing an appeal with the city administrator within ten working days after the first step hearing date. 
(2)  The decision in the second step shall be rendered within five working days of presenting the grievance at the second step level. The employee may appeal the second step decision by filing an appeal with the city administrator within ten working days after the second step hearing date. 
(3)  The decision in the third step shall be rendered within ten working days of presenting the grievance at the third step level. 
(Ord. No. 1597, § 1597.01, 8-11-93; Ord. No. 1692, § 1692.01, 5-26-99) 
Sec. 2-262. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1720, adopted Aug. 8, 2001 deleted § 2-262 which pertained to warning and reprimand and derived from Ord. No. 1597, § 1597.01, adopted Aug. 11, 1993. 
Sec. 2-263. - Suspension. 
(a)  The city administrator may suspend any employee with pay pending completion of an investigation which may result in suspension or dismissal when the city administrator believes such action is in the best interest of the city. 
(b)  The city administrator may suspend an employee without pay for up to 30 calendar days in any one calendar year for any cause. 
(Ord. No. 1597, § 1597.01, 8-11-93; Ord. No. 1720, 8-8-2001) 
Sec. 2-264. - Demotion and dismissal. 
    Recommendations for demotion or dismissal shall be made by the city administrator to the city council. 
(Ord. No. 1597, § 1597.01, 8-11-93; Ord. No. 1720, 8-8-2001) 
Secs. 2-265-2-310. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - FINANCIAL AFFAIRS[15] 

Footnotes: 
--- (15) --- 
Cross reference- Finance department, § 2-171 et seq.; licenses, permits and miscellaneous business regulations, ch. 11. 
State Law reference- Municipal finances generally, M.S. §§ 412.241 et seq. 

Sec. 2-311. - Accounting and general principles. 
(a)  The financial affairs of the city shall be conducted in accordance with the governmental accounting and financial reporting principles established by the National Council on Governmental Accounting; accepted standards of the Government Finance Officers of America for governmental accounting adopted by the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants and requirements of the state. 
(b)  The city shall operate a modified accrual accounting system. 
(Code 1985, § 202.04(A), (B)) 
Sec. 2-312. - Closing, transfer and creation of funds. 
    The city council shall possess the sole authority to close funds and transfer sums of money between funds. The finance director is given the authority to create new funds as necessary. 
(Code 1985, § 202.04(C); Ord. No. 1568, § 1568.02, 5-22-91) 
Sec. 2-313. - Purchasing procedures. 
    All purchases shall meet the following conditions in this section. 
(1)  All purchases shall be in accordance with the adopted budget and purchasing procedures. 
(2)  The head of the department for which the service, equipment or supplies are ordered must recommend that the order be placed. 
(3)  The service, equipment or supplies must be necessary to the operation of the department. 
(4)  Where equipment is ordered to replace obsolete, damaged or wornout equipment, the new equipment shall as nearly as possible equal that which it replaces in design, function. 
(5)  The city council shall by resolution establish the purchasing dollar limits where city council approval shall be required before proceeding. 
(6)  All claims resulting from orders placed by the purchasing agent shall be audited by the city council. 
(7)  Where bidding is required to be used, bidding procedures shall be consistent with state law. 
(8)  The city council expressly retains its power to disaffirm any order or contract entered into by the purchasing agent on behalf of the city, in the same manner and to the same extent that such power existed prior to the adoption of this Code. 
(Code 1985, § 202.10(D); Ord. of 1568, § 1568.03, 5-22-91) 
State Law reference- Municipal purchases, M.S. § 471.345 et seq. 
Sec. 2-314. - Partial payment of assessments. 
    The finance director/deputy city clerk is given the authority to accept partial payment of special assessments as follows: 
(1)  The special assessment originally adopted must be for a term of more than five years. 
(2)  For non-Green Acres property the amount of the prepayment shall be the larger of the following amounts: 
a.  Twenty percent of the special assessment originally adopted. 
b.  Two hundred dollars. 
(3)  For Green Acres property the amount of the prepayment shall be equal to the annual installment that would apply if the property were not classified Green Acres, or larger. 
(4)  Any partial prepayment shall not impact the amount of the annual installment required as a result of the original assessment adopted. Any prepayments made shall reduce the term of the assessment, not the annual installment. 
(Ord. No. 1613, § 1613.01, 7-13-94) 
Secs. 2-315-2-330. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - ABANDONED, ETC., PROPERTY[16] 

Footnotes: 
--- (16) --- 
Cross reference- Junked vehicles, abandoned vehicles, etc., § 15-26 et seq. 
State Law reference- Public hearing required for reduction of abandoned property by eminent domain, Minn. Stat. § 117.0412; unclaimed utility deposits, Minn. Stat. § 345.34; acquisition of title to abandoned tangible personal property, Minn. Stat. § 345.75; disposal of unclaimed property, M.S. § 471.195. 

Sec. 2-331. - Scope. 
    This article applies to all money and property that comes into the possession of the city in the course of its municipal operations. This article does not apply to motor vehicles or animals. 
(Code 1985, § 1202.01) 
Sec. 2-332. - Administrative procedures authorized; disposal. 
    The public safety department shall establish administrative provisions for receiving and safekeeping money and property coming into possession of the city in the course of its municipal operations. A receipt shall be issued to any person finding such property or money and causing it to be delivered to the custody of the city. Such property shall be stored in a safe place and such money deposited with the public safety department for a period of 60 days unless claimed by the true owner. Upon expiration of the 60 days, the property or money be subject to disposal under this article as unclaimed property or money. 
(Code 1985, § 1212.01; Ord. No. 1763, 8-10-2005; Ord. No. 1772, 4-26-2006) 
Sec. 2-333. - Claims by owner. 
    During the 60 days referred to in section 2-332, the public safety department may deliver such property or order such money paid to the true owner thereof upon satisfactory proof of ownership, after ten days notice by mail to other persons who may have asserted a claim of true ownership. In the event ownership cannot be determined to the satisfaction of the public safety department, it may refuse to deliver such property or order the payment of such money to any person until ordered to do so by a court. 
(Code 1985, § 1212.02; Ord. No. 1763, 8-10-2005; Ord. No. 1772, 4-26-2006) 
Sec. 2-334. - Claim by finder. 
    If the true owner does not claim property or money during the 60 days referred to in section 2-332, the clerk may release such unclaimed property or order such unclaimed money to be paid to the person who found same, if at the time of delivery to the city such finder indicated in writing that he wished to assert a claim to the property or money as a finder. 
(Code 1985, § 1212.03; Ord. No. 1772, 4-26-2006) 
Sec. 2-335. - Transfer of unclaimed moneys to general fund. 
    If any money is not claimed by the true owner or by the finder within the 60 days referred to in section 2-332, the public safety department shall cause such money to be transferred to the general fund. 
(Code 1985, § 1212.04; Ord. No. 1763, 8-10-2005; Ord. No. 1772, 4-26-2006) 
Sec. 2-336. - Public sale. 
(a)  Upon expiration of the 60 days referred to in section 2-332 unclaimed property remaining in the possession of the city shall be appropriated for the city's use or, shall be sold at public sale by an outside auctioneer. The public safety department shall cause ten days published notice of the public sale in the official newspaper, describing therein the article to be sold and the date, time and place of sale. Any unclaimed property offered for public sale but not sold, and not suitable for appropriation for city use, shall be deemed to be of no value and shall be disposed of in such manner as public safety department directs. 
(b)  Upon completion of a public sale of unclaimed property, the public safety department shall cause the proceeds therefrom to be deposited in the General Fund and recorded to the Miscellaneous Revenue Account: 101-000-00-00000-4395. 
(Code 1985, § 1212.06; Ord. No. 1763, 8-10-2005; Ord. No. 1772, 4-26-2006; Ord. No. 1901, § 1, 4-22-2015 ) 
Sec. 2-337. - Claim by former owner after public sale. 
    The former true owner of property sold at public sale according to the provisions of section 2-336, upon application to the public safety department within six months of the date of public sale and upon furnishing satisfactory proof of former ownership, be paid the respective sale price proceeds from the general fund. 
(Code 1985, § 1212.07; Ord. No. 1763, 8-10-2005; Ord. No. 1772, 4-26-2006) 
Sec. 2-338. - Summary disposal. 
    The public safety department may, without notice and in such manner as it determines to be in the public interest, dispose summarily of any property coming into its possession which it determines to be dangerous or perishable. It shall make a record of the pertinent facts of the receipt and disposal of such property. 
(Code 1985, § 1212.08; Ord. No. 1763, 8-10-2005; Ord. No. 1772, 4-26-2006) 
Secs. 2-339-2-355. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - BOARDS AND COMMISSIONS[17] 
Footnotes: 
--- (17) --- 
Cross reference- Parks and recreation commission, § 16-16 et seq.; planning and zoning commission, § 17-16 et seq.; board of zoning appeals, § 24-27 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-356. - Boards, committees, commissions and task forces. 
(a)  The city council may, by resolution or ordinance, create from time to time such boards, committees, or task forces as it deems to be necessary for the proper management and operation of the city, and by resolution appoint individual members to serve on the same. 
(b)  The city council shall prescribe the rules, regulations, procedures and duties of the boards, committees, commissions and task forces that it appoints in the resolution or ordinance creating them. 
(c)  The boards, committees, commissions or task forces appointed by the city council may exercise all duties that the city council has legally assigned to them. They can have the authority to conduct investigations and to make recommendations. They may not, however, make decisions on behalf of the city council. 
(d)  The city council may from time to time appoint individuals to represent the city on boards, committees, commissions or task forces to which the city belongs. 
(e)  Absences from one-third of the duly called meetings of the board, committee, commission or task force shall constitute the automatic resignation of the appointed member. 
(f)  A meeting is defined, for the purpose of this subsection, as a regularly scheduled meeting, special meeting, special event (an event scheduled outside of the regular and special meeting format) and a cancelled meeting. 
(g)  No individual shall serve more than two consecutive terms on a commission, authority or board unless approved by the city council in accordance with this section. The city council may appoint an individual to serve more than two consecutive terms if: 
(1)  The city council makes a finding that there are circumstances which make such appointment desirable, and; 
(2)  At least three-fourth of the city council votes to make such finding and appointment. 
(Ord. No. 1680, § 1680.1, 8-13-98; Ord. No. 1783, § 1783.01, 12-13-2006) 
State Law reference- City departments and boards, Minn. Stat. § 412.111. 
Secs. 2-357-2-365. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT COMMISSION 

Sec. 2-366. - Created. 
    There is created an economic development commission. 
(Code 1985, § 228.01; Ord. No. 1642, § 1642.01, 1-10-96) 
State Law reference- Economic development, Minn. Stat. § 469.001 et seq. 
Sec. 2-367. - Membership. 
(a)  The economic development commission shall be composed of up to 11 members. 
(b)  Members of the commission shall be appointed for three-year staggered terms except that any person appointed to fill a vacancy occurring prior to the expiration of the term for which the predecessor had been appointed shall be appointed only for the remainder of such term. Upon the expiration of their term of office the member shall be considered to be serving until a successor is appointed. 
(c)  Reserved. 
(d)  All members of the commission serve at the pleasure of the city council. Vacancies shall be filled by appointment of the city council. 
(e)  Commission members shall serve without compensation. 
(f)  Members of the commission shall be residents of the city while serving on the commission and shall represent as broad a range as possible of interests in the economic development function. 
(Code 1985, §§ 228.05, 228.07-228.10; Ord. No. 1642, § 1642.01, 1-10-96; Ord. No. 1703, § 1703.01, 8-9-2000; Ord. No. 1824, § 1824.01, 10-14-2009; Ord. No. 1891, § 1, 11-12-2014 ; Ord. No. 1925 , § 1, 11-30-2016) 
Sec. 2-368. - Officers and meetings. 
(a)  The chairperson of the economic development commission shall be appointed annually by the city council. The chairperson may be removed by a majority vote of the city council. The chairperson shall assure fulfillment of the duties and responsibilities of the commission. 
(b)  The commission shall adopt rules and procedures not inconsistent with the provisions of this division and as may be necessary for the proper execution and conduct of business. 
(c)  The commission shall establish its meeting times and place at its first meeting of the calendar year. Other meetings may be called by the chairperson as needed. 
(d)  The council shall appoint such additional standing committees to undertake portions of the commission's work program as it shall deem desirable. Standing committees shall consist of not more than 11 members who shall be appointed for three-year staggered terms. A member of the economic development commission shall serve as chair of said committee. 
(e)  The city council or commission may appoint temporary task forces to undertake special projects. 
(Code 1985, §§ 228.06, 228.11, 228.12; Ord. No. 1642, § 1642.01, 1-10-96; Ord. No. 1824, § 1824.02, 10-14-2009; Ord. No. 1861, § 1861.01, 10-24-2012; Ord. No. 1891, § 1, 11-12-2014 ) 
Sec. 2-369. - Staff. 
    The city administrator shall assign staff from the community development department to provide support to the economic development commission. The city council shall annually appoint members to serve as liaison to the commission. 
(Code 1985, § 228.13; Ord. No. 1642, § 1642.01, 1-10-96; Ord. No. 1824, § 1824.03, 10-14-2009; Ord. No. 1891, § 1, 11-12-2014 ) 
Sec. 2-370. - Economic development commission functions. 
(a)  The economic development commission shall act as a coordinating body and resource agency for economic development matters. 
(b)  The general purpose of the commission is to study, review and prepare recommendations for the city council regarding matters of economic development policy. 
(c)  In fulfillment of its purposes and duties, the commission shall: 
(1)  Propose an economic development plan for the city to include long-term strategies for economic development. 
(2)  Recommend economic development policies and programs to the city council. 
(3)  Work with the city council, and staff in promoting the city and attracting economic growth and development and retaining businesses in the community. 
(4)  Make an annual report to the city council regarding achievements towards fulfillment of such programs. 
(5)  Develop and recommend methods to stimulate positive interest in economic growth and development. 
(6)  Evaluate and make recommendations on city financing of economic development activities. This would include tax increment financing, loans, grants or other incentives which may be used. It may also include review of city financing of public projects, as requested by the city council. 
(Code 1985, §§ 228.02-228.04; Ord. No. 1642, § 1642.01, 1-10-96; Ord. No. 1824, § 1824.04, 10-14-2009; Ord. No. 1891, § 1, 11-12-2014 ; Ord. No. 1959 , § 1, 2-27-2019) 
DIVISION 3. - AUDIT AND INVESTMENT COMMISSION[18] 

Footnotes: 
--- (18) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1824, § 1824.05, adopted October 14, 2009, retitled Div. 3, Investment Strategy Commission to read as herein set out. 

Sec. 2-371. - Created. 
    There is created an audit and investment commission. 
(Ord. No. 1646, 8-14-96; Ord. No. 1824, § 1824.06, 10-14-2009) 
Sec. 2-372. - Membership. 
(a)  The audit and investment commission shall be composed of up to seven members. 
(b)  The members of the commission shall be appointed for three-year staggered terms except that any person appointed to fill a vacancy created by a member's failure to complete his/her term shall be appointed for the remainder of such term. Upon the expiration of the term of office a member shall be considered to be serving until a successor is appointed. 
(c)  A council member shall be appointed annually by the city council to serve on the audit and investment commission as an ex officio member of the commission privileged to speak on any matter without a vote and shall provide a liaison between the commission and the city council. 
(d)  All members of the commission serve at the pleasure of the city council. Vacancies shall be filled by appointment by the city council. 
(e)  Members of the commission shall serve without compensation. 
(f)  Members of the commission shall be residents of the city while serving on the commission and should possess a basic understanding of governmental financial reporting and auditing as well as experience with internal controls and understanding of audit committee functions. 
(Ord. No. 1646, 8-14-96; Ord. No. 1688, § 1688.01, 11-30-98; Ord. No. 1704, § 1704.01, 8-9-2000; Ord. No. 1824, § 1824.07, 10-14-2009; Ord. No. 1846, § 1846.01, 12-14-2011; Ord. No. 1926 , § 1, 11-30-2016) 
Sec. 2-373. - Officers and meetings. 
(a)  The city council shall appoint one member of the commission to serve as chairperson for a term of one year. The chairperson shall assure the fulfillment of the duties and responsibilities of the commission and shall preside over the meetings of the commission. 
(b)  The meeting schedule for the audit and investment commission shall be established by the commission, but they shall meet at least annually to review the audit report. Additional meetings may be called by the chairperson as needed. 
(c)  Four members of the audit and investment commission shall serve as a quorum for the purposes of holding a meeting. 
(Ord. No. 1646, 8-14-96; Ord. No. 1824, § 1824.08, 10-14-2009; Ord. No. 1846, § 1846.01, 12-14-2011; Ord. No. 1926 , § 1, 11-30-2016) 
Sec. 2-374. - Staff. 
    The city administrator shall assign one member of the finance department to serve as staff liaison to the audit and investment commission. 
(Ord. No. 1646, 8-14-96; Ord. No. 1824, § 1824.09, 10-14-2009) 
Sec. 2-375. - Purpose and responsibilities. 
(a)  The audit and investment commission is hereby established to assist the city council in discharging its responsibilities for the annual review of the city's financial affairs. The responsibilities of the audit and investment commission shall include: 
(1)  Recommend to the city council an independent firm of certified public accountants to perform the annual audit. 
(2)  Review the scope of the proposed audit for each year and the audit procedures to be utilized with the independent auditors. 
(3)  Review the annual financial statements, management letter and state legal compliance audit. 
(4)  Analyze significant findings in the audit report and make recommendations to the city council regarding such findings. 
(5)  Review with the independent auditors and city staff the adequacy and effectiveness of the accounting and financial controls and make recommendations to the city council regarding such internal controls. 
(6)  Review of city council salaries and benefits with recommendations as they deem appropriate. 
(7)  Report its actions to the city council at least once annually with recommendations that they deem appropriate. 
(8)  Review the city's investment policy, portfolio and practices as outlined in the city's investment policy. 
(9)  Serve as a communication link between the city council and the independent auditor. 
(Ord. No. 1824, § 1824.10, 10-14-2009; Ord. No. 1908, § 1, 1-13-2016 ) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1824, § 1824.10, adopted October 14, 2009, repealed the former § 2-375, and enacted a new § 2-375 as set out herein. The former § 2-375 pertained to functions and derived from Ord. No. 1646, 8-14-96. 
Secs. 2-376-2-390. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT AUTHORITY 

Sec. 2-391. - Created. 
(a)  The Woodbury Economic Development Authority (the "Woodbury Economic Development Authority") has been duly organized pursuant to M.S. §§ 469.090 to 469.1082, as amended. 
(b)  The legislature of the State of Minnesota has enacted M.S. ch. 462C, as amended (the "Housing Act") to regulate the planning and implementation of single family housing programs and multifamily housing developments and has provided for the financing of such single family housing programs and multifamily housing developments in accordance with the provisions of the Housing Act. 
(c)  Pursuant to the Housing Act, a city is authorized to develop and administer programs of making or purchasing mortgage or rehabilitation loans to finance the acquisition or rehabilitation of single family housing by low and moderate income persons and families anywhere within its boundaries, or making or purchasing loans to finance multifamily housing developments. 
(d)  Pursuant to the Housing Act, the city has the power to authorize an economic development authority acting within the city to exercise, on behalf of the city, the powers conferred by the Housing Act. 
Accordingly, the Woodbury Economic Development Authority is hereby authorized to exercise on behalf of the City of Woodbury, all of the powers conferred by the Housing Act. 
(Ord. No. 1767, §§ 1-5, 12-20-2005; Ord. No. 1916, § 1, 6-8-2016 ) 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 1767, §§ 1-5, adopted December 20, 2005, did not specifically amend the Code. Therefore, such ordinance has been added as § 2-391 at the editor's discretion. 
State Law reference- City authority to establish economic development authority, Minn. Stat. § 469.091. 
DIVISION 5. - HOUSING AND REDEVELOPMENT AUTHORITY 

Sec. 2-392. - Housing and Redevelopment authority in and for the City of Woodbury, Minnesota. 
(a)  The housing and redevelopment authority in and for the City of Woodbury, Minnesota (the "Woodbury HRA") has been duly organized pursuant to M.S. §§ 469.001-469.047, as amended. 
(b)  The Legislature of the State of Minnesota has enacted M.S. Ch. 462C, as amended (the "Housing Act"), to regulate the planning and implementation of single family housing programs and multifamily housing developments and has provided for the financing of such single family housing programs and multifamily housing developments in accordance with the provisions of the Housing Act. 
(c)  Under the terms of the Housing Act, a city is authorized to develop and administer programs of making or purchasing mortgage or rehabilitation loans to finance the acquisition or rehabilitation of single family housing by low and moderate income persons and families anywhere within its boundaries, or making or purchasing loans to finance multifamily housing developments or the rehabilitation of multifamily housing developments. 
(d)  Under the terms of the Housing Act, the city has the power to authorize the Woodbury HRA to exercise, on behalf of the city, the powers conferred by the Housing Act. 
(e)  Accordingly, the Woodbury HRA is hereby authorized to exercise on behalf of the city, all of the powers conferred by the Housing Act. 
( Ord. No. 1884, 8-6-2014 ; Ord. No. 1917, § 1, 6-8-2016 ) 
DIVISION 6. - WOODBURY PARKS AND NATURAL RESOURCES 

Sec. 2-393. - Woodbury parks and natural resources commission in and for the City of Woodbury, Minnesota. 
(a)  There is created the Woodbury Parks and Natural Resources Commission. 
(b)  Membership. 
(1)  The Woodbury Parks and Natural Resources Commission shall be composed of a chairperson and six members all of whom shall be appointed and serve at large plus up to two Woodbury resident students that are attending high school at the 11th grade level. 
(2)  Members of the commission shall be appointed upon majority consent of the council for staggered terms of three years, for a vacancy the appointment shall be only for the remainder of such term and for a student, the appointment shall be only for one year. 
(3)  The mayor shall appoint a council member to serve as an ex officio member of the commission privileged to speak on any matter without a vote and shall provide a liaison between the commission and the city council. 
(4)  Members of the commission shall be residents of the city while serving on the commission and shall represent as broad a range as possible of interests in the park, natural resources, and recreation function. 
(5)  Commissioners shall serve without compensation. 
(c)  Officers and meetings. 
(1)  The Woodbury Parks and Natural Resources Commission shall generally meet on the first Tuesday of each month at 7:00 p.m. at the Woodbury Municipal Building, with the schedule and location subject to change with the required notification. 
(2)  The commission shall adopt such rules and procedures consistent with these provisions as may be necessary for the proper execution and conduct of business. 
(3)  The city council shall appoint one member of the commission to serve as chairperson for a term of one year. The chairperson may be removed with the majority vote of the council. The chairperson shall: 
a.  Preside over meetings of the commission. 
b.  Appear or appoint a representative to appear as necessary before other city advisory commissions and the city council to present the view point of the commission on matters pertaining to park, natural resources, and recreation functions as they relate to business under consideration by said commissions or city council. 
c.  Serve as the liaison with other governmental and volunteer units in matters relating to the park, natural resources, and recreation functions. 
d.  The vice-chairperson shall be appointed annually by the chairperson. The vice-chairperson shall perform such duties as may be assigned by the chairperson and shall assume the responsibilities of the chair in absence of the chairperson. 
(d)  Staff. The city administrator shall assign one member of the administrative staff to serve as staff liaison to the Woodbury Parks and Natural Resources Commission. The staff member assigned shall perform such administrative duties on behalf of the commission as may be assigned. 
(e)  Functions. The Woodbury Park and Natural Resources Commission has three main functional areas: 
(1)  Parks. 
(2)  Natural resources. 
(3)  Recreation. 
(f)  Responsibilities of the commission. 
(1)  Advise the city council and other advisory commissions regarding matters relevant to park, natural resources, and recreation functions, reflecting the attitudes and concerns of the citizens of Woodbury. 
(2)  Serve as a forum for the citizens of the city to voice their opinions regarding park, natural resource, and recreation functions. 
(3)  Review the comprehensive plan and park classification system and make recommendations for any changes it deems necessary. 
(4)  Monitor the implementation of the comprehensive plan and park classification system. 
(5)  Encourage the conservation and preservation of natural resources in order to achieve a more sustainable community. 
(6)  Review recreation programming as needed and provide input on areas needing improvement. 
(7)  Review development proposals relating to park dedication, park and trail issues, and pedestrian and bicycling access, consistent with adopted policies, ordinances, regulations and the comprehensive plan. 
(8)  Encourage maximum waste reduction, reuse, and recycling from Woodbury residents, businesses, and city operations.
