    Application for a variance shall be made in writing by the subdivider at the time when the preliminary plat or minor subdivision is filed for consideration. The procedure for reviewing any variance application shall be in accordance with chapter 24, article II, division 6. 
(Ord. No. 1864, § 1864.01, 11-14-2012) 
Sec. 21-35. - Planned unit developments. 
(a)  In recognition of changing trends, techniques, procedures, financing and materials in the processes of urban and rural development, the council and planning and zoning commission may provide flexibility to strict adherence to the standards in this chapter through a planned unit development. The procedure for review and approval of a planned unit development shall be in accordance with chapter 24, article IV. 
(b)  Unless waived by the community development director, all data required on a preliminary plat and on a final plat as set forth in this chapter, including streets, utility easements, existing or proposed subdivisions of ownership and such other information, if any, as required by this chapter, shall be required as a part of the planned unit development conditional use permit as set forth in chapter 24, article IV. Such waiver shall not constitute a verification that all required data has been submitted. 
(c)  A concept preliminary plat may be reviewed as part of a concept planned unit development as set forth in section 24-207. 
(Ord. No. 1864, § 1864.01, 11-14-2012) 
Secs. 21-36-21-45. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PRELIMINARY PLAT 

Sec. 21-46. - Generally. 
(a)  Before subdividing any tract of land into two or more parcels as defined in section 21-6, an owner or subdivider shall file with the community development director an application for a preliminary plat. 
(b)  Pursuant to Minnesota Statutes, an application for a preliminary plat shall be approved or denied within 120 days from the date of its official and complete submission, meaning all required data in section 21-48, unless a time waiver is granted by the subdivider. 
(Ord. No. 1864, § 1864.01, 11-14-2012) 
Sec. 21-47. - Sketch plan. 
(a)  Subdividers are encouraged to prepare, for review with the community development director, the city engineer and other staff, a proposed subdivision sketch plan. In order to be most useful a sketch plan should contain the following information: 
(1)  Site location map showing major street, school location, commercial centers and other significant developments. 
(2)  Tract boundaries. 
(3)  North point and scale. 
(4)  Streets within and adjacent to tract. 
(5)  Topography and physical features. 
(6)  Proposed general street design. 
(7)  Proposed lot size and orientation. 
(b)  The sketch plan will be considered as the basis for discussion between the subdivider and city staff. Submission of such sketch plan shall not constitute formal filing of a preliminary plat. The city staff will, on the basis of such sketch plan, unofficially advise the subdivider of the extent to which the proposed subdivision conforms to city requirements and will discuss possible modifications. 
(Ord. No. 1864, § 1864.01, 11-14-2012) 
Sec. 21-48. - Required data. 
    The materials, information and drawings required for submission of a preliminary plat application are listed in this section. A preliminary plat application shall include or have attached thereto all materials, information and drawings listed in this section to be deemed complete. 
(a)  Complete application form signed by all property owners. 
(b)  All required filing fees and escrows in the amount established by resolution along with an executed escrow deposit agreement. This escrow will be used for public expenses in connection with approval or denial of the preliminary plat and any final plat which may thereafter be submitted. 
(c)  Location map showing the site in relation to the surrounding area and important elements, including major roadways, schools and public facilities, commercial centers and other significant developments and parks. 
(d)  A statement of the present ownership of all land included within the proposal and a list of property owners within 500 feet of the outer boundaries of the project area to be obtained from the Washington County Surveyor's office or a title or abstract company. Two sets of mailing labels shall be provided. 
(e)  Copies of the preliminary plat and related plans, size, format and number of sets to be identified on the application form provided by the community development director, including the following information: 
(1)  Identification and description: 
a.  Proposed name of subdivision in accordance with section 21-82. 
b.  Full legal description of property and property identification number(s). 
c.  Names and addresses of the owner, and any agent having control of the land, subdivider, surveyor, engineer, and designer of the plan. 
d.  Graphic scale not less than one inch to 100 feet. 
e.  North point. 
f.  Date of preparation. 
(2)  Existing conditions: 
a.  Boundary line survey, including measured distances and angles which shall be tied to the nearest one-quarter corner or section corner by traverse. 
b.  Existing zoning classifications for land in and abutting the subdivision. 
c.  Site statistics as follows: 
1.  Total gross acreage. 
2.  Total right-of-way acreage. 
3.  Total outlot acreage. 
4.  Existing wetland area, any impact area and any replacement area. 
5.  Percent open space. 
6.  Gross and net densities. 
7.  Park land dedication. 
8.  Lot acreage. 
9.  Minimum width at front setback. 
10.  Percent driveway coverage, if applicable, per street. 
d.  Location, right-of-way width, and names of existing or platted streets or other public ways. Parks and other public lands, permanent buildings and structures, easements and section and corporate lines within the preliminary plan and to a distance 200 feet beyond shall also be indicated. 
e.  Location and size of existing sewers, water mains, culverts or other underground facilities within the preliminary plan area and to a distance of 200 feet beyond. Such data as grades, invert elevations, and locations of catch basins, manholes, hydrants and street pavement width and type, shall also be shown. 
f.  Boundary lines of adjoining unsubdivided or subdivided land, within 200 feet, identified by name and ownership, but including all contiguous land owned or controlled by the subdivider. 
g.  Topographic data, including contours at vertical intervals of not more than two feet, except where the horizontal contour interval is 100 feet or more, a one-foot vertical interval shall be shown. Water courses, ponds, shoreland, flood plains, tree lines and wooded areas, steep slopes, rock outcrops, power transmission poles and lines and other significant features shall also be shown. U.S.G.S. datum shall be used for all topographic mapping. 
h.  A copy of all proposed private restrictions. 
i.  Soil borings and/or percolation or other tests if requested by the city engineer. 
j.  All existing wetlands are to be delineated pursuant to Minnesota Wetland Conservation Act, 1991 and adopted rules thereto and section 27-15. 
k.  Tree inventory in accordance with section 27-40. 
(3)  Subdivision design features to be shown: 
a.  Layout of proposed streets, showing right-of-way widths and proposed names of streets. The name of any street heretofore used in the city or its environs shall not be used, unless the proposed street is an extension of an already named street, in which event the name shall be used. 
b.  Locations and widths of proposed alleys, bicycle or pedestrian ways and utility easements. 
c.  Layout numbers and preliminary dimensions of lots and blocks and phasing plan. 
d.  Minimum front and side street building setback lines. 
e.  Typical lot easements, front, rear and side. 
f.  Utility plan showing the location and size of all existing and proposed sanitary sewer lines, storm sewer lines and water mains to 200 feet beyond the plat boundary including pipe diameters, rim and invert elevations and pipe gradients. 
g.  Gradients of all proposed streets. 
h.  Proposed grading plan with topographic data for 200 feet around the subject property or around major features with intervals not exceeding two feet except where the horizontal contour interval is 100 feet or more in which case a one-foot vertical interval shall be shown. Proposed grading plan shall include: 
1.  All proposed storm sewer and stormwater management facilities. 
2.  Emergency overflow elevations and locations for all street and rear yard catch basins, ponds, lakes, wetlands, swales, etc. 
3.  Proposed type and elevation of all buildings. 
4.  All drainage swales clearly defined with contours, spot elevations and drainage arrows. 
5.  Flood plain locations and flood elevations if the subdivision is located in or adjacent to a 100-year floodplain. 
i.  Areas, other than streets, alleys, pedestrian ways and utility easements, intended to be dedicated or reserved for public use, including the size of such area or areas in acres. 
(4)  Other information: 
a.  Statement of the proposed use of lots stating type of residential buildings with number of proposed dwelling units; type of business or industry so as to reveal the effect of the development on traffic, fire hazards, and congestion of population. 
b.  Source of water supply. 
c.  Provisions for sewage disposal, surface water, drainage, and flood control. 
d.  Landscape plan may be required to show location of plantings, size of plantings, mature heights and spread and root type. 
e.  Tree replacement calculations and planting plan, if required. 
f.  If any zoning changes are contemplated, the proposed zoning plan for the areas, including dimensions. 
g.  Such other information as may be requested by the city engineer or planning and zoning commission. 
h.  Where the subdivider's property is adjacent to property with subdivision potential, the subdivider shall submit a preliminary plan of the adjacent property so as to show the possible relationships between the proposed subdivision and future subdivision. 
(Ord. No. 1864, § 1864.01, 11-14-2012) 
Sec. 21-49. - Processing and decision. 
(a)  Upon receiving a complete application, as determined by staff review, staff shall refer copies of the preliminary plat to other applicable public agencies as required to receive written comments including but not limited to the following: 
(1)  Any proposed subdivision which includes land abutting upon any existing or established trunk highway or proposed highway which has been designated by a centerline order filed in the office of the county recorder shall first be presented to the commissioner of transportation for his or her written comments and recommendations. 
(2)  Where any subdivision includes land abutting upon an existing or established county or county state aid highway, it shall first be submitted to the county engineer for his or her written comments and recommendations. 
(3)  The commissioner of transportation and/or the county engineer shall submit the written comments and recommendations to the city within 30 days after receipt by them of the proposed subdivision. Final action on the proposed minor subdivision by the city shall not be taken until after these required comments and recommendations have been received or until the 30-day period has elapsed, whichever is less. 
(4)  Failure to obtain the written comments and recommendations of the commissioner of transportation or the county engineer shall in no manner affect the title to the land included in the proposed subdivision. 
(b)  Upon receiving a complete application, as determined by staff, the community development director shall refer the preliminary plat and application to the planning and zoning commission and, if required, to the park and recreation commission for review and recommendation. 
(c)  Notice of the planning and zoning commission and park commission meetings scheduled for the consideration of the application should be sent to all property owners within 500 feet from the outer boundaries of the property in question at least ten days in advance of the meeting date. A notice of the public hearing date shall also be provided. Failure of a property owner to receive mailed notice or defects in the notice shall not invalidate the proceedings. 
(d)  The planning and zoning commission shall make its report to the city council. The planning and zoning commission may return a conditional report. 
(e)  The city council shall, after receipt and placing on file the report of the planning and zoning commission, hold a public hearing on the application. The community development director shall schedule the public hearing and shall cause notice of the time, place and purpose of said hearing to be published at least ten days prior to the date of the hearing in the official newspaper of the city. 
(f)  The city council may require such changes or revisions and may impose such conditions upon approval as it deems necessary for the health, safety, general welfare and convenience of the city. 
(g)  The city council may deny the preliminary plat if it makes any of the following findings: 
(1)  That the proposed subdivision conflicts with the purpose and intent of the city's comprehensive plan, any adopted master plan, the zoning ordinance, this chapter and all chapters of the City Code. 
(2)  That the physical characteristics of the site including but not limited to topography, vegetation, susceptibility to flooding, water storage and retention are such that the site is not suitable for the type of development or use contemplated. 
(3)  That the design of the subdivision or required improvements are likely to cause substantial and irreversible environmental damage. 
(4)  That the design of the subdivision or required improvements will be detrimental to the health, safety and general welfare of the public. 
(5)  That the design of the subdivision will conflict with easements of record. 
(6)  That the subdivision is premature as determined by the standards in article II of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 1864, § 1864.01, 11-14-2012) 
Sec. 21-50. - Effect of approval. 
(a)  If the preliminary plat is approved, such approval shall not constitute final acceptance of the subdivision. The approval of a preliminary plat is an acceptance of the general layout as submitted and indicates to the subdivider that he or she may proceed toward fulfilling the necessary steps for approval of the final plat in accordance with the terms of approval and with division 3 of this article. 
(b)  Subsequent approval will be required of the engineering proposals pertaining to water supply, storm drainage, sewerage and sewage disposal, sidewalks, gas and electric service, grading, gradients and roadway widths and the surfacing of streets and by other public officials having jurisdiction, prior to the approval of the final plat by the city council. 
(c)  For a period of one year following preliminary plat approval, unless the subdivider and the city agree otherwise, no amendment to the comprehensive plan or other official controls shall apply to or affect the use, development, density, lot size or lot layout that was approved. 
(Ord. No. 1864, § 1864.01, 11-14-2012) 
Sec. 21-51. - Expiration of approval. 
    Unless the city council specifically approves a different time period, the approval of a preliminary plat shall expire one year from the date it was approved unless the subdivider has filed a complete final plat application, or, unless the subdivider submits a written request for an extension thereof and said request is approved by the city council prior to the one-year expiration date. 
(Ord. No. 1864, § 1864.01, 11-14-2012) 
Sec. 21-52. - Effect of denial. 
(a)  If the preliminary plat is denied, the reasons for such action shall be recorded in the proceedings and transmitted to the applicant. 
(b)  If the preliminary plat is denied by the council, no re-application by a property owner for a preliminary plat shall be submitted to the city within a 12-month period following a denial of such a request, except the city council may permit a new application or reconsideration if, in the opinion of the city council, new evidence or change of circumstances warrants it. 
(Ord. No. 1864, § 1864.01, 11-14-2012) 
Sec. 21-53. - Change to approved plan. 
    Should a subdivider desire to amend the preliminary plan as approved, he or she may resubmit the amended plan, which shall follow the same procedure, unless the amendment is, in the opinion of the city, of such a scope as to constitute a new plan, in which case it shall be re-filed as a new preliminary plat. For any amendment, the same filing fee and escrow shall be paid as if filing for a new plan. 
(Ord. No. 1864, § 1864.01, 11-14-2012) 
Secs. 21-54-21-60. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - FINAL PLAT 

Sec. 21-61. - Generally. 
(a)  The owner or subdivider shall file a complete application for final plat of a proposed subdivision not later than one year after the date of approval of the preliminary plat. 
(b)  Pursuant to Minnesota Statutes, an application for a final plat shall be approved or denied within 60 days from the date of its official and complete submission, meaning all required data in section 21-62, unless a time waiver is granted by the subdivider. 
(c)  The final plat will have incorporated all conditions, changes or modifications required; in all other respects it shall conform to the approved preliminary plat. It may constitute only that portion of the approved preliminary plat which the subdivider proposed to record and develop at the time, provided that such portion conforms to all the requirements of this chapter and any approved phasing plan as part of the preliminary plat and/or planned unit development. 
(d)  The final plat of a proposed subdivision shall be prepared by a land surveyor who is registered in the State of Minnesota and shall conform to all state and county requirements and the requirements of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 1864, § 1864.01, 11-14-2012) 
Sec. 21-62. - Required data. 
    The materials, information and drawings required for submission of a final plat application are listed in this section. A final plat application shall include or have attached thereto all materials, information and drawings listed in this section to be deemed complete. 
(a)  Complete application form signed by all property owners. 
(b)  All required filing fees and escrows in the amount established by resolution along with an executed escrow deposit agreement. This escrow will be used for public expenses in connection with approval or disapproval of the final plat. 
(c)  Location map showing the site in relation to the surrounding area. 
(d)  Certifications showing that all taxes and special assessments currently due on the property to be subdivided have been paid in full. 
(e)  All other plans, documents, calculations or exhibits to demonstrate compliance with the requirements of the preliminary plat approval. 
(f)  Calculations as required to fulfill plat monitoring data requested by the Metropolitan Council. 
(g)  Copies of the final plat and any related plans, size, format and number of sets to be identified on the application form provided by the community development director, shall include the following information: 
(1)  Accurate angular and lineal dimensions for all lines, angles, and curvatures used to describe boundaries, streets, alleys, easements, areas to be reserved for public use. Dimensions of lot lines shall be shown in feet and hundredths; no ditto marks will be permitted. When lot lines are not at right angles to the street right-of-way line, the width of the lot shall be indicated at the building set-back line. 
(2)  A numbered identification system for all lots and blocks. 
(3)  A boundary line survey including the measured distances and angles and the true distance and bearing between a known point on the boundary and the nearest official monument which shall be accurately described on the plat. 
(4)  Municipal, township, county or section lines accurately tied to the lines of the subdivision by distances and angles. 
(5)  Radii, internal angles, points and curvatures, tangent bearings, and lengths of all arcs. 
(6)  Name and location of the subdivision. 
(7)  Name and accurate location of all monuments. 
(8)  Graphic scale and north point. 
(9)  Names of all streets and right-of-way widths. 
(10)  Location of water bodies and wetland boundaries. 
(11)  Form of approval of city as required. 
(12)  Form for approval by county authorities as required. 
(Ord. No. 1864, § 1864.01, 11-14-2012) 
Sec. 21-63. - Processing and decision. 
(a)  Prior to release of the final plat for recording, the subdivider shall incorporate all conditions, changes or modifications required and submit to the city all required information that may include, but is not limited to, the following: 
(1)  An up-to-date certified abstract of title or registered property report and such other evidence as the city attorney may require showing title or control. 
(2)  Deeds dedicating land or monetary dedication for parks and open space. 
(3)  Deeds dedicating any other lands or easements to the city. 
(4)  Fully executed development agreement and any other related, required documents including but not limited to subordination agreements, consents to plat, tax increment financing agreements, tax abatement agreements or payment in lieu of taxes (PILOT) agreements. 
(5)  All fees, charges, contributions, financial securities and escrows outlined in the development agreement. 
(b)  No changes, erasures, modifications or revisions shall be made in any final plat after approval has been given by the city council and/or endorsed in writing on the plat. 
(c)  The subdivider shall, immediately upon recording, furnish the city with a tracing and three prints of the final plat showing evidence of the recording. 
(d)  Upon receiving approval of the final plat for a portion of the approved preliminary plat the subdivider is not required to request a continuation of the recognition of the preliminary plat so as to maintain its approval. 
(Ord. No. 1864, § 1864.01, 11-14-2012) 
Sec. 21-64. - Effect of approval. 
    For a period of two years following final plat approval, unless the subdivider and the city agree otherwise, no amendment to the comprehensive plan or other official controls shall apply to or affect the use, development, density, lot size or lot layout that was approved. 
(Ord. No. 1864, § 1864.01, 11-14-2012) 
Sec. 21-65. - Expiration of approval. 
    Unless the city council specifically designates a different time period, the approval of a final plat shall expire one year from the date it was approved unless recorded with the county register of deeds or registrar of titles. 
(Ord. No. 1864, § 1864.01, 11-14-2012) 
Sec. 21-66. - Effect of denial. 
    If the final plat is denied, the reasons for such action shall be recorded in the proceedings and transmitted to the applicant. 
(Ord. No. 1864, § 1864.01, 11-14-2012) 
Secs. 21-67-21-75. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - MINOR SUBDIVISIONS AND BOUNDARY LINE ADUSTMENTS 

Sec. 21-76. - Minor subdivisions of residential property. 
(a)  In the case of a subdivision of residential zoned property resulting in two or less parcels, situated in a locality where conditions are well defined, the city council may exempt the subdivider from complying with some of the requirements of these regulations. In the case of a request to subdivide a lot which is a part of a recorded plat, or where the subdivision is to permit the adding of a new parcel of land to an abutting lot or to create not more than two new lots, and the newly created property lines will not cause any resulting lot to be in violation of these regulations or the zoning ordinance, the division may be approved by the city council after submission of a survey by a registered land surveyor showing the original lot and the proposed subdivision. The newly created parcels shall meet all requirements of the zoning ordinance. 
(1)  Topographic data at two-foot contour intervals, driveway access points, drainage plans, and, if necessary, soil tests for the installation of a subsurface sewage treatment system shall be submitted for minor subdivision review. 
(2)  A certificate of survey shall be prepared by a registered land surveyor showing the boundaries of the newly created lots. 
(3)  Prior to approval of a minor subdivision, the city council reserves the right to require the dedication of streets, utility easements, or public park land or cash in lieu of land. 
(b)  In cases where the new lot and resulting lots created exceed 20 acres and have 500 feet of frontage on a public road, subdivision approval is not required. 
(c)  Any proposed minor subdivision which includes land abutting upon any existing or established trunk highway or proposed highway which has been designated by a centerline order filed in the office of the county recorder shall first be presented to the commissioner of transportation for his or her written comments and recommendations. 
(d)  Where any minor subdivision includes land abutting upon an existing or established county or county state aid highway, it shall first be submitted to the county engineer for his or her written comments and recommendations. 
(e)  The commissioner of transportation and/or the county engineer shall submit the written comments and recommendations to the city within 30 days after receipt by them of the proposed minor subdivision. Final action on the proposed minor subdivision by the city shall not be taken until after these required comments and recommendations have been received or until the 30-day period has elapsed, whichever is less. 
(f)  Failure to obtain the written comments and recommendations of the commissioner of transportation or the county engineer shall in no manner affect the title to the land included in the proposed minor subdivision. 
(Ord. No. 1864, § 1864.01, 11-14-2012) 
Sec. 21-77. - Land division/boundary adjustment. 
(a)  In any case where the division of land into two or more lots or parcels for the purpose of transfer of ownership or building improvement is not specifically provided for in the provision of these regulations, a description of such land division shall be filed with the director of community development. No building permit shall be issued for any construction, enlargement, alteration, or repair, demolition, or moving of any building or structure on any lot or parcel resulting from such division, until such division has been approved by the director of community development. A certified survey of the proposed division shall be submitted. 
(b)  In cases where adjoining contiguous property owners wish to exchange or otherwise divide land with the intent of enlarging one of the parcels and as a result of such division, neither parcel will be non-conforming in accordance with the zoning ordinance, approval must be obtained from the director of community development. The applicant must submit the same documents and information required for an application. Some of the requirements for minor subdivision approval may be waived; however, the newly acquired land must be combined on the deed for recording purposes as the remainder of the owners' property. 
(Ord. No. 1864, § 1864.01, 11-14-2012) 
Secs. 21-78-21-80. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - DESIGN AND ENGINEERING STANDARDS 

Sec. 21-81. - Conformity with comprehensive plan. 
    The proposed subdivision shall conform to the comprehensive plan. 
(Ord. No. 1864, § 1864.01, 11-14-2012) 
Sec. 21-82. - Subdivision names. 
    The proposed name of the subdivision shall not duplicate or too closely approximate phonetically the name of any other subdivision in the city. The city council shall have the final authority to approve the name of the subdivision. 
(Ord. No. 1864, § 1864.01, 11-14-2012) 
Sec. 21-83. - Engineering design standards, design specifications and details. 
    Public and private improvements shall comply with the standards set forth in the city's engineering design standards, design specifications and details, which are hereby adopted by reference. 
(Ord. No. 1864, § 1864.01, 11-14-2012) 
Sec. 21-84. - Street plan. 
(a)  The arrangement, character, extent, width, grade, and location of all streets in a subdivision shall conform to the comprehensive plan; the city's roadway design principles; relevant provisions of chapter 27, environmental management; other applicable city policies and ordinances; and to these regulations, and shall be considered in their relation to existing and planned streets, to reasonable circulation of traffic, to topographical conditions, to run-off of stormwater, to public convenience and safety, and in their appropriate relation to the proposed uses of the land to be served by such streets. 
(b)  Adequate right-of-way for collector and arterial roadways shall be provided in accordance with the city's roadway design principles. All local through streets shall have a minimum right-of-way of 60 feet. 
(c)  The arrangement of streets in new subdivisions shall make provision for the appropriate continuation of the existing streets in adjoining areas. 
(d)  Where adjoining areas are not subdivided, but may be subdivided, the arrangement of streets in a new subdivision shall make provision for the proper projection of streets into adjoining areas by carrying the new streets to the boundaries of the new subdivision at appropriate locations. 
(e)  Names of new streets in subdivisions shall not duplicate existing or platted street names unless a new street is a continuation of or in alignment with the existing or platted street, in which event it shall bear the same name of the existing or platted street so in alignment. 
(Ord. No. 1864, § 1864.01, 11-14-2012) 
Sec. 21-85. - Street standards. 
(a)  Generally. All right-of-way widths and pavement widths (face to face of curb) in subdivisions shall conform to the city's adopted transportation plan and roadway design principles. Greater or lesser widths may be required depending upon anticipated traffic volumes, planned function of the street and character of planned abutting land uses at the sole discretion of the city. 
(b)  Gradient. Street grades shall be as approved by the city engineer. All centerline gradients in subdivisions shall be at least 0.5 percent and shall not exceed the following: 
Classification Gradient (percent) Arterial and collector streets 4 Local streets 8  
(c)  Cul-de-sac. The maximum length of cul-de-sac streets in subdivisions shall be no greater than 500 feet measured along the centerline from the intersection of origin to end of right-of-way and shall conform to the city's cul-de-sac policy. 
(d)  Reserve strips. Reserve strips controlling access to streets in subdivisions shall be prohibited except under approved conditions. 
(e)  Private streets. Private streets in subdivisions shall only be approved in accordance with the city's adopted private street policy. 
(f)  Hardship to owners of adjoining property avoided. Street arrangements in subdivisions shall not be such as to cause hardship to owners of adjoining property in platting their own land and providing convenient access to it. 
(g)  Street signs. Street signs shall conform to the Manual for Uniform Traffic Control. 
(h)  Street lighting. Street lighting shall be required in accordance with the engineering design standards, design specifications and details. 
(Ord. No. 1864, § 1864.01, 11-14-2012) 
Sec. 21-86. - Street lighting. 
(a)  Street lighting in accordance with the engineering design standards, design specifications and details shall be required in all new residential subdivisions approved after March 21, 1981. 
(b)  Residential street lighting systems located on city property shall be owned, installed, operated and maintained by the electric utility company. The city and the electric utility company shall enter into a contractual agreement on the rate and maintenance of the street lighting system under the group V lighting rate plan. It shall be the responsibility of the developer to: 
(1)  Pay the electric utility company for the purchase of all components of the street lighting system. 
(2)  Pay the electric utility company any cost incurred in the installation of the street lighting units not covered in the electric utility company rate for this service. This payment shall be required to be guaranteed as part of the plan A security as outlined in the developer agreement. 
(3)  The style of lighting system, along with the purchase and installation costs, will be established by the city council. An alternate lighting system style will require city approval. The developer shall pay any additional costs. 
(4)  All of the street lighting costs shall be guaranteed as part of the plan A security as outlined in the developer agreement. 
(c)  As of March 12, 1981, street lighting operating expenses in all new residential subdivisions, except as stated in paragraph (b)(1) above shall be charged equally to the parcels of that subdivision based on the type of lighting system installed. The charge shall be uniform and imposed as a utility rate and be included as a street lighting charge on the quarterly utility bill. The street light utility rates are adopted annually as an amendment to section 2-3. 
(d)  Billing payment and penalty provisions shall be enforced consistent with those in chapter 23, article II, division 3. 
(Ord. No. 1864, § 1864.01, 11-14-2012) 
Sec. 21-87. - Intersections. 
(a)  Angle. The angle formed by the intersection of streets in subdivisions shall not be less than 90 degrees. 
(b)  Size. Intersections in subdivisions of more than four corners shall be prohibited. 
(c)  Grade. The grade of a roadway at an intersection where a vehicle must stop shall be one percent or less for at least 100 feet from the stop location. 
(d)  Spacing. Intersection spacing shall conform to the city's access management policy. 
(e)  Alignment. All proposed intersections of roadways or driveways shall line up with existing roadways or driveways on adjacent properties. If adjacent roadways or driveways do not existing, topography and adjacent lot lines shall be considered in regard to future intersection spacing. 
(f)  Controls. All traffic control shall be reviewed and approved by the city engineer and the city council in accordance with adopted policies. 
(Ord. No. 1864, § 1864.01, 11-14-2012) 
Sec. 21-88. - Curb and gutter. 
    Concrete curb and gutter shall be included as a part of the required street surface improvement in subdivisions and shall be designed for installation along both sides of all roadways. Installed curb and gutter shall be of a type approved by the city engineer and consistent with the city's engineering design standards, design specifications and details and street and sidewalk construction policy. 
(Ord. No. 1864, § 1864.01, 11-14-2012) 
Sec. 21-89. - Paths and sidewalks. 
    Paths and sidewalks for pedestrian use shall be installed in subdivisions with new street construction as required by the city engineer and/or in accordance with the comprehensive plan. The necessary right-of-way to accommodate the path or sidewalk on one or both sides of the roadway shall be dedicated to the city. 
(a)  Widths. The minimum width of a sidewalk shall be five feet, and the minimum width of a path shall be eight feet. 
(b)  Grades. Preferred grades shall not exceed a two percent cross slope away from the property line, and the profile shall not exceed five percent or the adjacent roadway grade. 
(c)  Construction. The minimum standards for all required sidewalks shall be concrete four inches thick placed on a six-inch compacted gravel base. The minimum standards for all required paths shall be bituminous three inches thick placed on a six-inch compacted gravel base. 
(d)  Location. Sidewalks and paths shall be placed in the public right-of-way or on property dedicated to the city by deed or easement and placed no closer than one foot from the property line. 
(Ord. No. 1864, § 1864.01, 11-14-2012) 
Sec. 21-90. - Grading. 
(a)  Permit required. No grading shall occur on site without a land disturbance permit in accordance with chapter 7, land disturbance and erosion and sediment control. A land disturbance permit may not be issued until after the city council has granted the applicant a preliminary plat approval unless otherwise approved by the city council. 
(b)  Major roadways. All subdivisions shall grade adjacent major roadway rights-of-way in conjunction with project grading to cross-sections approved by the city engineer. 
(c)  Adjacent property. No grading shall be approved that creates negative impacts on stormwater management infrastructure or on adjacent properties. 
(d)  Slopes. No slope on site shall be greater than 3:1 excluding retaining walls. 
(e)  Rear yard. All residential units shall have a minimum 25-foot useable rear yard with a maximum grade of ten percent. 
(Ord. No. 1864, § 1864.01, 11-14-2012) 
Sec. 21-91. - Water supply. 
(a)  Unless guided as rural or urban estate by the comprehensive plan, municipal water must be available to serve the proposed subdivision. Available shall mean existing or readily extended and funded consistent with the phasing in the comprehensive plan, the capital improvements program and any relevant city ordinances, plans and policies. If guided as rural or urban estate by the comprehensive plan, private well(s) must be able to adequately serve the proposed subdivision. 
(b)  Extensions of the public water supply system shall be designed so as to provide public water service to each lot. 
(c)  Municipal water mains shall be extended to the property line as determined by the city engineer to allow for future extension to serve adjacent properties. 
(Ord. No. 1864, § 1864.01, 11-14-2012) 
Sec. 21-92. - Sewage disposal. 
(a)  Unless guided as rural or urban estate by the comprehensive plan, municipal sanitary sewer must be available to serve the proposed subdivision. Available shall mean existing or readily extended and funded consistent with the phasing in the comprehensive plan, the capital improvements program and any relevant city ordinances, plans and policies. If guided as rural or urban estate by the comprehensive plan, a private subsurface sewage treatment system must be able to adequately serve the proposed subdivision. 
(b)  Extensions of the public sanitary sewer system shall be designed so as to provide sewer service to each lot. 
(c)  Municipal sanitary sewer shall be extended to the property line as determined by the city engineer to allow for future extension to serve adjacent properties. 
(Ord. No. 1864, § 1864.01, 11-14-2012) 
Sec. 21-93. - Stormwater management and drainage. 
(a)  A complete and adequate stormwater management system design shall be required for the subdivision in accordance with the adopted surface water management plan and chapter 27, division 3. 
(b)  Municipal storm sewer shall be extended to the property line as determined by the city engineer to allow for future extension to serve adjacent properties. 
(Ord. No. 1864, § 1864.01, 11-14-2012) 
Sec. 21-94. - House services. 
    Each house service shall be extended from the main to the property in accordance with the engineering design standards, design specifications and details where a cap or plug shall be placed until the service is extended to the structure. 
(Ord. No. 1864, § 1864.01, 11-14-2012) 
Sec. 21-95. - Utilities location. 
    All utility installation in public rights-of-way shall be in accordance with chapter 20, article V. When practicable and feasible, all utilities shall be placed underground. All underground work shall be completed prior to street surfacing. All utility lines for telephone and electrical service shall be placed in rear line easements when carried on overhead poles. 
(Ord. No. 1864, § 1864.01, 11-14-2012) 
Sec. 21-96. - Easements. 
(a)  Utilities. Standard lot easements for residential lots shall be ten feet in front and rear yards and five feet in side yards. Standard lot easements for commercial lots shall be ten feet in all yards. Required easement width shall be at least ten feet on each side of the pipe or structure. If the utilities are deeper than ten feet, the easement width for each lot is calculated at a 1:1 depth to width ratio from the outside edge of the utility with the easement adjusted to the next largest five-foot increment. 
(b)  Drainage. Easements in subdivisions shall be provided over lakes, wetlands, stormwater ponds, watercourses or drainage swales whether or not shown in the comprehensive plan, at least one foot above the 100-year high water level and to a sufficient width to provide proper maintenance and protection and to provide for stormwater run-off and installation and maintenance of storm sewers as determined by the city engineer in accordance with chapter 27, divisions 2 and 3. 
(c)  Dedication. Easements in subdivisions shall be dedicated for the required use on the plat. 
(Ord. No. 1864, § 1864.01, 11-14-2012) 
Sec. 21-97. - Lot trees. 
    It is required that in all residential subdivisions, trees shall be planted on each lot. Trees shall not be planted in any city right-of-way. Lot trees shall be planted as follows: 
(a)  The number of plantings required is three times the number of residential lots on the preliminary plat. A minimum of one tree shall be planted on each lot for single-family detached and twin home subdivisions. When a twin home is located on one lot, one tree is required for each unit. The remaining trees shall be dispersed throughout the subdivision, except that entry landscaping will not count toward the required plantings. 
(b)  No one tree species shall consist of more than 30 percent of the trees in a particular subdivision proposal. 
(c)  Specific tree locations are subject to the location of easements and the approval of the community development director or designee. Easements that contain public structures and are intended for maintenance access and utilities should be kept free of landscaping. 
(d)  A tree inventory consistent with chapter 27, division 4, and a tree planting plan shall be submitted with the preliminary plat. The tree planting plan shall include the proposed tree location, species and size identification. 
(e)  Deciduous trees shall be a minimum of two to two and one-half inches in diameter, and conifers shall be a minimum of three feet in height. The tree diameter will be measured six inches above grade. 
(f)  Tree species shall be consistent with the recommended list provided by the city. 
(Ord. No. 1864, § 1864.01, 11-14-2012) 
Sec. 21-98. - Blocks. 
(a)  Factors governing dimensions. In a subdivision, block length and width or acreage within bounding streets shall be such as to accommodate the size of residential lots required in the area by the zoning ordinance and to provide for convenient access, circulation control, and safety of street traffic. 
(b)  Length. Block lengths in a subdivision shall not exceed 1,800 feet nor be less than 300 feet except where topography or other conditions justify a departure from the standard as approved by the city engineer. 
(c)  Arrangement. A block in a subdivision shall be so designed as to provide two tiers of lots, unless it adjoins a major arterial or collector street, lake, wetland, park or other natural feature where it may have a single tier of lots. 
(Ord. No. 1864, § 1864.01, 11-14-2012) 
Sec. 21-99. - Lots. 
(a)  Arrangement. The lot arrangement shall be such that there will be no foreseeable difficulties for reasons of topography or other conditions, in securing building permits to build on all lots in compliance with the zoning ordinance. 
(b)  Frontage. All lots in subdivisions shall meet the zoning ordinance requirements for frontage on a publicly dedicated street to be measured at the minimum front yard setback and shall have direct access to an improved street. 
(c)  Lot dimensions. All lot dimensions shall comply with the minimum standards specified in the zoning ordinance except as herein provided. 
(d)  Corner lots. Corner lots in subdivisions shall be platted at least 15 feet wider than interior lots. 
(e)  Butt lots. Butt lots in subdivisions shall be platted at least five feet wider than the average width of interior lots in the block. The use of same shall be avoided when possible. 
(f)  Side lot lines. Side lines of lots in subdivisions shall be substantially at right angles to the street line. 
(g)  Natural features. In the subdividing of any land, regard shall be shown for all topography, natural features, such as tree growth, watercourses, historic spots, or similar conditions, which if preserved will add attractiveness and stability to the proposed development. 
(h)  Lot remnants. All remnants of lots below minimum size left over after subdividing of a larger tract must be added to adjacent lots, or a plan shown as to future use rather than allowed to remain as unusable parcels. 
(i)  Access to arterials. In the case where a proposed subdivision plat is adjacent to an arterial, there shall be no direct vehicular access from individual lots to such streets and roads. In the platting of small tracts of land fronting on limited access highways or arterials where there is no other alternative, a temporary entrance may be granted; as neighboring land becomes subdivided and more preferable access arrangements become possible, such temporary access permits shall become void. 
(j)  Through or double frontage lots. Through or double frontage lots in subdivisions shall not be permitted except where such lots back onto an arterial or major highway. Such lots shall have additional depth of 25 feet for screen planting along rear lot line. 
(Ord. No. 1864, § 1864.01, 11-14-2012) 
Sec. 21-100. - Monuments. 
    Monuments of a permanent character (pipes, steel rods, concrete, or equivalent) shall be placed in each corner or angle on the boundary of the subdivision and at each corner of each lot in accordance with state law. 
(Ord. No. 1864, § 1864.01, 11-14-2012) 
Sec. 21-101. - Protection of environmental resources and natural features. 
    All subdivisions shall meet the requirements of chapter 27. The city council reserves the right to deny an application for a subdivision inconsistent with chapter 27 and/or the natural resource management and environmental protection chapter of the comprehensive plan. Subdivisions should seek to preserve natural features such as large trees, watercourses, scenic points, historical spots and similar community assets to add attractiveness and stability to the proposed development of the property. 
    Subdivision review shall be coordinated with the requirements and procedures for environmental assessment worksheet and impact statements contained in chapter 27, division 7. Any mandatory environmental assessment worksheet or impact statement as required by the Minnesota Environmental Quality Board Regulations shall be submitted as part of the application for preliminary plat approval. 
(Ord. No. 1864, § 1864.01, 11-14-2012) 
Sec. 21-102. - Solar access planning. 
    Wherever practical, all new subdivisions should be designed to accommodate extensive use of passive and active solar energy systems with special attention given to street, lot and building orientation. 
(Ord. No. 1864, § 1864.01, 11-14-2012) 
Secs. 21-103-21-130. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - REQUIRED IMPROVEMENTS AND DEVELOPMENT AGREEMENTS 

Sec. 21-131. - Improvements listed and described. 
    Required improvements are necessary to avoid findings of premature subdivision as outlined in article II of this chapter. Prior to the awarding of a public construction contract or the authorization of private construction, the subdivider shall agree via a development agreement to install, in conformity with approved construction plans and in conformity with all applicable standards and ordinances, all required improvements including, but not limited to, the following: 
(a)  Streets. 
(b)  Sanitary sewer. 
(c)  Water main. 
(d)  Surface water management facilities. 
(e)  Grading and erosion control. 
(f)  Sidewalks and trails. 
(g)  Street lighting. 
(h)  Street signs and traffic control. 
(i)  Landscaping. 
(j)  Public and private utility infrastructure. 
(j)  Miscellaneous facilities. 
(Ord. No. 1864, § 1864.01, 11-14-2012) 
Sec. 21-132. - Payment for installation. 
    The required improvements to be installed by the subdivider shall be installed and financed as identified in the development agreement. 
(Ord. No. 1864, § 1864.01, 11-14-2012) 
Sec. 21-133. - Required agreement providing for installation. 
(a)  Prior to installation of any required improvements and prior to awarding of a public construction contract or authorization of private construction, the subdivider shall enter into a contract in writing with the city requiring the subdivider to furnish and construct the improvements and in accordance with plans and specifications and usual contract conditions, which shall include provision for supervision of details of construction by the city engineer and grant to the city engineer authority to correlate the work to be done under said contract by any subcontractors authorized to proceed thereunder and with any other work being done or contracted by the city in the vicinity. 
(b)  For residential developments, the agreement shall require the subdivider to provide security as identified in the adopted Public Infrastructure Improvements for New Residential Development policy adopted herein by reference. 
(c)  Commercial developments shall provide security requirements as identified in the development agreement. 
(Ord. No. 1864, § 1864.01, 11-14-2012) 
Sec. 21-134. - Financial guarantee. 
    The contract provided for in section 21-132 shall require the subdivider to provide appropriate security as follows: 
(a)  For all residential developments a security, as identified in the Public Infrastructure Improvements for New Residential Development policy and the Surety Policy, adopted herein by reference, shall be provided to the city to secure future public improvements. 
(b)  For all commercial developments, security shall be posted as identified in the development agreement prior to commence of improvements. 
(c)  All securities for both residential and commercial developments shall be issued in a form acceptable, at its sole discretion, to the city. The city shall be entitled to reimburse itself out of said deposit for any cost and expense incurred by the city for completion of the work in case of default of the subdivider under said contract, and for any damages sustained on account of any breach thereof. Upon completion of the work and termination of any liability, the balance remaining in the deposit shall be refunded to the subdivider. 
(Ord. No. 1864, § 1864.01, 11-14-2012) 
Sec. 21-135. - Construction plans. 
    Construction plans for the required improvements conforming in all respects with the standards of the city engineer and the ordinances of the city shall be prepared at the subdivider's expense by a professional engineer who is registered in the state of Minnesota. The plans shall contain his or her seal. Such plans together with the quantities of construction items shall be submitted to the city engineer for his or her approval and for his or her estimate of the total cost of the required improvements. Upon approval they shall become a part of the required contract. 
(Ord. No. 1864, § 1864.01, 11-14-2012) 
Sec. 21-136. - Inspection. 
    All required improvements on the site that are to be installed under the provisions of this chapter shall be inspected during the course of construction by the city engineer or designee at the subdivider's expense, and acceptance shall be subject to the city engineer's certificate of compliance with the contract. 
(Ord. No. 1864, § 1864.01, 11-14-2012) 
Sec. 21-137. - Trunk facilities. 
    Where a water main, sanitary sewer, storm drain or similar facility should be constructed at a larger size to serve areas outside the subdivision the ultimate facility required must be constructed unless waived by the city engineer. Potential credits for increased expenses may be allocated in the development agreement. 
(Ord. No. 1864, § 1864.01, 11-14-2012) 
Sec. 21-138. - Installation by city. 
    The city shall install any or all of the required public improvements unless private construction is authorized by the city administrator in accordance with the adopted Public Infrastructure Improvements for New Residential Development policy for residential projects or through the development agreement for commercial projects. 
(Ord. No. 1864, § 1864.01, 11-14-2012) 
Secs. 21-139-21-155. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - PARKS AND OPEN SPACES 

Sec. 21-156. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this article is to establish parkland dedications for all new subdivisions, including minor subdivisions and cluster developments, to be developed for residential, commercial, industrial, office or other uses or as a planned unit of development or mobile home park. 
(Ord. No. 1864, § 1864.01, 11-14-2012) 
Sec. 21-157. - Dedication required. 
(a)  Where a proposed park, playground or public open space as shown on the comprehensive plan is embraced in part or in whole by the boundary of a proposed subdivision to be developed for residential, commercial, industrial or other uses, or as planned development and such public sites are not dedicated, such public ground shall be reserved and no action taken towards approval of a preliminary or final plat for a period not to exceed 120 days to allow the opportunity to consider and take action towards acquisition of such public ground or park by purchase or other causes. 
(b)  In all new subdivisions, including minor subdivisions and cluster developments, to be developed for residential, commercial, industrial, or other uses, or as a planned development, a reasonable portion of each proposed subdivision shall be dedicated to the public for public use as parks, playgrounds, public open space or trails unless otherwise waived by the city council. 
(c)  No areas may be dedicated for public use until such areas have been approved as being in conformance with the comprehensive plan and as being suitable and needed for the public health, safety, convenience and general welfare. 
(d)  No dedication shall be accepted by the city council until the same has been referred to the planning and zoning commission for review and recommendation. The area to be dedicated shall be delineated on the preliminary plat and final plat. No dedication shall be accepted by the city council until the same has been referred to the park and recreation commission. 
(e)  Dedication requirements are as follows: 
(1)  Residential. New residential subdivisions, minor subdivisions and cluster developments shall dedicate ten percent of the gross land area for park and open space purposes. At the sole discretion of the city council, a fee may be paid in lieu of land dedication in an amount established by ordinance from time to time by the city council. Assisted living developments, as defined in section 24-3, shall dedicate ten percent of the gross land area for park and open space purposes or, at the sole discretion of a city, pay a fee in lieu of land dedication at the commercial rate established by ordinance from time to time by the city council. 
(2)  Commercial, industrial and office. New commercial, industrial and office subdivisions shall dedicate ten percent of the gross land area for park and open space purposes. At the sole discretion of the city council, a fee may be paid in lieu of land dedication in an amount established by ordinance from time to time by the city council. 
(3)  Schools and places of worship. Public elementary and secondary schools and places of worship, as defined in section 24-3, are exempt from park dedication requirements. 
(d)  Additional requirements. 
(1)  Dedication of land is based on the gross land area less any area dedicated at no cost to the city for major road rights-of-way and regional stormwater management facilities. Fee in lieu of dedication shall be based on the gross land area less any area dedicated at no cost to the city for major road rights-of-way and regional stormwater management facilities or per residential unit. 
(2)  Factors used in evaluating land proposed for park dedication include size, shape, topography, hydrology, tree cover, access and location. 
(3)  Lakes, wetlands, utility corridors, stormwater management areas and drainage ways below the ordinary high water elevation shall not be credited for park dedication. 
(4)  Land area dedicated to the city shall be in addition to and not in lieu of private common recreation facilities and open space areas. In addition, private recreation facilities and open space areas shall not be credited toward park dedication requirements. 
(5)  Cash payments shall be paid by the subdivider no later than at the time the final plat or minor subdivision is released for recording. 
(6)  The city may elect to receive a combination of fees, land and/or development of the land for parks, playgrounds, public open space or trails. 
(7)  Planned unit developments with mixed land uses shall make cash and/or land contributions based upon the percentage of land devoted to the various uses. 
(8)  If land is dedicated, the developer shall rough grade the basic features at the time the subdivision is graded and shall restore the area as identified in the development agreement. 
(9)  Fees collected in lieu of land dedication must be used only for the acquisition and development or improvement of parks, recreational facilities, playgrounds, trails, or open space based on the approved park systems plan and must not be used for ongoing operation or maintenance of parks, recreational facilities, playgrounds, trails, or open space. 
(Ord. No. 1864, § 1864.01, 11-14-2012) 
Chapter 22 - SWIMMING POOLS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, ch. 6. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 22-1-22-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PRIVATE SWIMMING POOLS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal regulation of dangerous excavations, Minn. Stat. § 471.92. 

Sec. 22-16. - Definition. 
    In this article "private swimming pool" means any pool, tank, depression or excavation in or above ground, or other structure which shall cause retaining of water over a greater depth than 18 inches and/or having a larger plane surface of water greater than 150 square feet and which shall be designed or used for swimming, wading or immersion purposes by individuals, used or intended to be used solely by the owner, lessee or tenant thereof and his family and by friends invited to use it without payment of any fees. 
(Code 1985, § 309.01) 
Sec. 22-17. - Permit. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to construct, alter or repair a private swimming pool within the city without first having secured a permit therefor from the building official. An application for this permit shall be made on such form as may be furnished by the city, and shall be accompanied by complete plans and specifications for the pool, including the type and location thereof with respect to the boundary lines of the land of the applicant. The applicant shall pay the fees established by resolution for such permit. 
(b)  The building official may revoke any permit for failure to comply with this article. Before a permit is revoked, the pool owner shall have notice in writing listing and describing the instances of failure to comply with this article. The permit shall be reissued upon proper application and upon presentation of evidence that the deficiencies causing revocation have been corrected. 
(Code 1985, §§ 309.03, 309.04) 
Sec. 22-18. - Compliance with article. 
    It is unlawful for any person to own or maintain a private swimming pool that does not comply with this article. 
(Code 1985, § 309.05) 
Sec. 22-19. - Modifications. 
(a)  The council may make modifications in this article in individual cases, upon showing of good cause, with respect to the height, nature or location of the fence or wall, gates or latches, or the necessity therefor, provided the degree of protection is not reduced thereby. 
(b)  The council may permit other protective devices or structures to be used so long as the degree of protection afforded by the substitute devices or structures is not less than the protection afforded by the fence, gate and latch described in this article. 
(Code 1985, § 309.11) 
Sec. 22-20. - Setback requirements; location generally; drainage generally. 
    Pools for which a permit is required under this article shall not be located within ten feet of any side or rear lot line nor within six feet of any principal structure or frost footing. Pool shall not be located closer than ten feet to any portion of a private sewage system. Pools shall not be located within any required front yard. Pools shall be drained to the street storm sewer system unless otherwise authorized by the city. 
(Code 1985, § 309.06) 
Sec. 22-21. - Fences. 
(a)  All private swimming pools shall be completely surrounded by a fence or wall not less than four feet in height, which shall be so constructed as not to have openings, holes or gaps larger than four inches in either vertical or horizontal direction, except for doors and gates. The fence shall be of a type not readily climbed by children. A dwelling or accessory building may be used as part of such enclosure. An above-ground pool with a wall greater than four feet in height does not require a fence if the wall cannot be readily climbed by children. 
(b)  All gates or doors opening through such enclosure shall be equipped with a self-closing and self-latching device for keeping the gate or door securely closed at all times when not in actual use and be provided with hardware for permanent locking devices, except that the door of any dwelling which forms a part of the enclosure need not be so equipped. Pool gates shall be locked when the pool is not in use. 
(c)  When it is necessary to fill the pool prior to the installation of the required fencing, a temporary fence (such as snow fence) may be installed in a substantial manner; with the approval of the building official. The maximum time allowed for a temporary fence shall be 30 days. 
(d)  Fences must comply with fence ordinance chapter 6, article IV, of this Code. 
(Code 1985, § 309.07) 
Sec. 22-22. - Outdoor pool enclosures. 
    Outdoor pool enclosures, permanent or inflated shall be constructed in accordance with the Minnesota State Building Code including appendix chapter 55 (membrane structures). Enclosures shall be of a neutral color and designed to blend with the existing surroundings. The enclosure shall not exceed in height, the principal structure on the property nor shall the enclosure be more than 18 feet high. The enclosure requires a special use permit. 
(Code 1985, § 309.08) 
Sec. 22-23. - Above-ground pools. 
    Above-ground private swimming pools shall be protected in such a way that access ways, other than those afforded by the dwelling house or accessory buildings, shall be equipped with self-closing and self-latching gates or doors so these gates or doors are kept securely closed at all times when not in actual use. 
(Code 1985, § 309.09) 
Sec. 22-24. - Pool covers. 
    Pool covers, whether they can be locked or not, do not alone meet public safety requirements if the cover is of the type that can collect and hold natural water. 
Sec. 22-25. - Lighting, ventilation and electrical requirements. 
(a)  Where underwater lighting is used, such lights shall be spaced to provide illumination so that all portions of the pool and pool bottom may be readily seen without glare. 
(b)  All electrical wiring shall conform with the National Electrical Code approved by the National Fire Protection Association and shall be approved by the National Underwriters Laboratory and the state electrical inspector, with particular reference to article 680-20 (of the National Electrical Code.) 
(c)  Each underwater light shall be individually grounded by means of a screwed or bolted connection to the metal junction boxes which the branch circuit to the individual light precedes. Such junction boxes shall not be located in the pool deck. 
(d)  Service drop conductors and any other open overhead wiring shall not be installed above the swimming pool or surrounding area extending ten feet horizontally from the pool edge, or dividing structure, observation stands, towers or platforms. 
(Code 1985, §§ 309.12, 309.13) 
Sec. 22-26. - Shielding lights. 
    Lights used to illuminate any private swimming pool shall be so arranged and shaded as to reflect light away from adjoining premises. 
(Code 1985, § 309.14) 
Sec. 22-27. - Life-saving and emergency equipment. 
    All private swimming pools shall have: 
(1)  Life-saving equipment consisting of at least: 
a.  One ring buoy not more than 15 inches in diameter to which is attached a rope three-sixteenths-inch in diameter and of a length at least equal to the greatest dimension of the swimming pool. 
b.  One life pole, or shepherd's crook type of pole, at least ten feet long and having blunted ends, shall be provided. 
(2)  Emergency flood lighting that are electrically connected to a different circuit than used by the pool. 
The emergency equipment shall be used for emergency purposes only. 
(Code 1985, § 309.15) 
Sec. 22-28. - Polluted water. 
(a)  No body of water, whether it be a natural or an artificial body of water in the city, which contains sewage, waste, or other contaminating or polluting ingredients rendering the water hazardous to health shall be used for swimming or bathing by any person or persons. 
(b)  Water shall not be allowed to remain in any unused or abandoned pool. 
(Code 1985, § 309.16) 
Sec. 22-29. - City water supply. 
    There will be no cross-connections of the city water supply with any other source of water supply for the pool. The line from the city water supply to the pool shall be protected against backflow of polluted water by means of either an air gap, vacuum breaker or other adequate device to prevent back siphonage. 
(Code 1985, § 309.17) 
Sec. 22-30. - Bacteriological quality of water. 
    A sample of private swimming pool water shall be considered satisfactory when the total bacterial count at 35 degrees centigrade does not exceed 200 colonies per milliliter and no organisms of the E. Coli group are present in a ten milliliter portion or 100 milliliter portion as determined by the membrane filter method. If more than one sample out of seven collected on different dates is unsatisfactory procedures and interpretations relating to bacteriological quality shall be done in accordance with the Standard Methods for the Examination of Water, Sewage and Industrial Wastes, 11th edition (1960). 
(Code 1985, § 309.17) 
Sec. 22-31. - Pool filters. 
(a)  Every private swimming pool shall be equipped with a recirculating system capable of filtering the entire contents of the pool in 12 hours or less. 
(b)  Filters shall be capable of maintaining the clarity of the water to permit the ready identification, through an eight-foot depth of water, of a disc two inches in diameter which is divided into four quadrants in alternate colors of red and white. 
(c)  Filter capacity shall be such that it need not be cleaned more frequently than once every four days under proper conditions of water and operation. 
(d)  All pressure filters shall be equipped with influent and effluent pressure gauges to determine the pressure differential and frequency of cleaning. All other filter shall be equipped with at least one pressure vacuum or compound gauge, as applicable, which shall be positioned in such a way as to determine the differential across the filter and the need of cleaning. 
(e)  All pressure filter systems shall be equipped with an air release at the high point in the system. 
(f)  Operating instructions shall be posted on every filter system. All valves shall be properly designated, indicating their purpose. 
(g)  When dissimilar metals are used in the construction of the filter, which may set up galvanic currents, then suitable provision shall be made to resist electrolytic corrosion. 
(h)  Filters shall be so designed and installed that they can be readily disassembled and the filter elements removed. 
(Code 1985, § 309.19) 
Sec. 22-32. - Disinfection and chemical conditioning. 
(a)  Provision shall be made for the introduction into each private swimming pool water of accurate and controlled applications of a disinfectant in sufficient quantities to attain and maintain efficient bactericidal action while the pool is in use. 
(b)  Suitable methods shall be available to maintain a pH of the pool water between 7.2 and 8.2 and to maintain an alkalinity of not less than 50 ppm. 
(c)  The devices used to apply chlorine or its equivalent as a disinfectant shall be of such capacity as to maintain in all areas of the swimming pool at all times at least 0.5 ppm of free available residual chlorine or a residual level of another approved disinfectant which shall be of at least a proven equivalent disinfecting strength as 0.5 ppm of free available residual chlorine. 
(Code 1985, § 309.20) 
Sec. 22-33. - Chemical storage. 
    The storage of chemicals shall meet the requirements of the Uniform Fire Code. 
(Code 1985, § 309.21) 
Sec. 22-34. - Unnecessary noise. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to make, continue or cause to be made or continue at any private swimming pool or family pool any loud, unnecessary or unusual noise or any noise which annoys, disturbs, injures, or endangers the comfort, repose, health, peace, or safety of others. In the operation of a swimming pool, the use or permitting the use or operation of any radio, receiving set, musical instrument, phonograph or other machine or device for the producing or reproducing of sound in such a manner as to disturb the peace, quiet, and comfort of the neighboring inhabitants or at any time with louder volume than is necessary for convenient hearing of the person or persons who are in the swimming pool premises shall be unlawful. 
(Code 1985, § 309.22) 
Chapter 23 - WATER, SEWERS AND SEWAGE DISPOSAL[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Plumbing, § 6-76 et seq.; solid wastes, ch. 19. 
State Law reference- Municipal authority relative to waterworks and sewers, M.S. §§ 412.221, subd. 6, 11, 444.075 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 23-1. - Application of municipal wastewater sludges or septage on land. 
    No person shall use, spread or apply raw municipal wastewater sludge or septage from a subsurface sewage treatment system on any land in the city for any purpose. 
(Code 1985, § 1406.01; Ord. No. 1903, § 1, 8-12-2015 ) 
Secs. 23-2-23-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - MUNICIPAL WATER AND SEWER SYSTEMS[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal water systems, sewer systems, etc., M.S. § 444.075 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 23-16. - Scope. 
    The city's water and sewer systems shall be operated and maintained under the provisions of this chapter. 
(Code 1985, § 1111.02) 
Sec. 23-17. - Management, etc. 
    The public utilities division of the department of public works is responsible for the management, maintenance, care and operation of the water and sewer systems of the city. 
(Code 1985, § 1111.02) 
Sec. 23-18. - Additional rules. 
    The city council may prescribe additional rules and regulations for the municipal water and sewer systems. 
(Code 1985, § 1111.08) 
Sec. 23-19. - Districts generally. 
    The city council may establish water, sanitary sewer and storm sewer districts and establish area charges, connection charges and lateral charges for each district by resolution. 
(Code 1985, § 1111.03(A)(4)) 
Sec. 23-20. - Emergency water conservation. 
(a)  The city council may adopt a resolution from time to time imposing regulations pertaining to the conservation of water. Following the adoption of such a resolution, the city shall publish the regulations and post the regulations at the city hall and at such other public places as the city council may direct. 
(b)  The city council may, by resolution, approve emergency water regulation whenever the city council determines that a shortage of water supply threatens the city. The emergency regulations may limit the times and hours during which city water may be used for sprinkling, irrigation, car washing and other external purposes. After the publication of a notice setting forth the emergency restrictions for use of water, no person shall use or permit water to be used in violation of the resolution. 
(c)  If any customer uses water in violation of the terms of a resolution adopted by the city council, said customer shall be charged with sums as established by resolution for each day of violation, and the charge shall be added to the customer's next water bill. Continued violation shall be cause for discontinuance of water service. 
(Code 1985, § 1111.09; Ord. No. 1643, § 1643.01, 5-8-96) 
Sec. 23-21. - Inspections. 
    Subject to constitutional limitations, any authorized city employee or agent shall have the right to enter and be admitted to any lands and property in the city at any reasonable hour for the purpose of inspection of materials, plumbing work and fixtures of all kinds used by or in connection with the water and sewer systems. This shall also apply to all public and private hydrants for flushing maintenance and inspections. 
(Code 1985, § 1111.13; Ord. No. 1874, § 1, 1-8-2014 ) 
Sec. 23-22. - Liability of city. 
    The city shall not be held liable at any time for any deficiency or failure in the supply of water to the customer whether the same be occasioned by shutting off the water for repairs or connections or for any cause whatever. 
(Code 1985, § 1111.12) 
Sec. 23-23. - Service applications. 
    Applications for municipal water and/or sewer service shall be accepted only from property owners or their authorized agents. 
(Code 1985, § 1111.08) 
Sec. 23-24. - Implied consent to rules, regulations and rates. 
    Every person applying for water or sewer service, every owner of property for which any such application is made, every person accepting water or sewer service and every owner of property where such service is accepted subsequent to January 19, 1978 shall be deemed upon making such application or accepting such service to consent to all rules, regulations and rates as established by this article and as may be adopted by resolution or ordinance. 
(Code 1985, § 1111.07) 
Sec. 23-25. - Discontinuing service. 
(a)  The city reserves the right to discontinue service to any customer of the water and sanitary sewer system without notice when necessary for repairs, additional connections or reconnections, or when, in the judgement of the public works director or his/her designee, such action is necessary to protect the purity of the municipal water supply or the safety of the water system and/or the life, health, and safety of its customers. 
(b)  The city reserves the right to discontinue service to any customer of the water and sanitary sewer system for disregard of any rules or regulations in connection with the use or operation of the system. 
(c)  The city reserves the right to discontinue water and sanitary sewer service to any vacant property or premises without heat. 
(d)  The city reserves the right to discontinue service to any customer of the water and sanitary sewer system for nonpayment of charges or bills. 
(e)  The service of water or sanitary sewer shall not be shut off for nonpayment of charges or bills until notice and an opportunity for a hearing have first been given to the occupant and owner of the premises involved. The notice shall be personally served or delivered by certified mail and shall state that, if payment is not made before the date stated in the notice, but not less than ten days after the date upon which the notice is given, the water supply to the premises will be shut off. The notice shall also state that the occupant may, before such date, demand a hearing before the city council, in which case the supply will not be shut off until after the hearing is held. If, as a result of the hearing, the city council finds that the amount claimed owing is actually due and unpaid and that there is no legal reason why the water supply of the delinquent customer may not be shut off in accordance with this article, the city may then shut off the supply. 
(f)  Whenever any service has been discontinued for any reason including nonpayment of charges or bills or for disregard of any rules or regulations it shall not be resumed except upon payment of the charges or bills accrued together with interest thereon, at a rate to be determined by council resolution or compliance with the rules and regulations previously violated and payment to the city of a disconnect fee in the amount established by resolution. If shut off was implemented due to a seasonal service termination (irrigation service) no disconnect fee shall be collected. 
(Code 1985, § 1111.05(B); Ord. No. 1685, § 1685.01, 10-14-98; Ord. No. 1953 , § 1, 11-28-2018) 
Sec. 23-26. - Connection permits, fees, etc. 
(a)  No person shall make any type of connection to the water system, sanitary sewer system or storm sewer system except after making an application therefor on a form provided by the city and receiving a permit issued by the city for such purposes. 
(b)  The application shall include the legal description of the property to be served, the uses for which the connection is requested, and the size of the service line to be used. At the time of making such application there shall be paid to the finance director/deputy clerk fees established by resolution. 
(c)  No connection shall be made with respect to any sanitary sewer, water system or storm sewer system serving the property of any person or occupants of the land, parcel or premises affected that have not paid or provided for the payment of the full and proportionate share of the utilities. 
(d)  No connection shall be made to the water or sewer system until the applicant or owner pays a connection charge established by resolution. The connection fee shall be in addition to any other fees or charges required. 
(e)  For service to property to which service lines have not been previously run from the street laterals to the property line, the owner, occupant or user shall pay to the treasury a service line charge, the amount of which shall not be less than the city's cost of making the necessary connections, taps, and installation of pipe and appurtenances to provide service to the property and the necessary street repairs; provided, however, with the approval of the city, the owner or applicant shall have the right to contract directly with a licensed plumber for the installation and connection of the service line.
